content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												There are not enough 4x games placed in fantasy world, and that's a shame. I placed a lot of hope in Fallen Enchantress, as I saw many positive reviews on forums and gaming sites. The game itself is quite frankly...average. Or even below average. The system itself is good and fun, lot of items to loot, monsters to kill, researches to do, empires to dominate. When you add mods it is even better. The sad part, and what makes this game almost "♥♥♥♥♥♥" is that it is so bugged, that it makes it sometimes unplayable (for a lot of people, just check official forum support page). The games crashes a lot, there is some kind of problem with memory leaks. The grid on tactical map is almost invisible so it is hard to tell where your troops can move. Sometimes the turn doesn't want to end, and only way is to reset the whole game. What is shamefull, is that mods from players are much better than the "Vanilla" game itself. It pisses me off, to see "another dlc" every month, when they can't even fix basic problem with game (bugs, crashes and incredible bad game optimisation). In my opinion, the game itself is not worth the money. It can give a lot of fun, but at the same time the frustration is unbearable.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												It took me a little while to decide whether or not I'd recommend this game. To be honest, I'm somewhere around the middle. I almost certainly wouldn't recommend it to someone who wants something of the depth of the Civilization games, but I would recommend it to someone who is new to the genre. I decided to go with a thumbs up rating as it's not really deserving of a thumbs down.This is a perfectly fine game, I just feel that there's not much to it after a few games. It's great fun for those few games, but I've found it doesn't really bring much to the table and doesn't feel as randomized as it should. I played a few games and found the same events cropping up in each game and it got monotonous. It's possible that the various DLC will provide a lot more customisation and randomisation, but on paper it doesn't seem to deliver so I haven't tried. If you're looking to recreate that Civilization or similar 4x feeling, this probably isn't the right game for it. Sure, it has elements of Civilization: build cities, explore, build armies, etc, but its lacking depth. The Fantasy setting is great and the addition of RPG elements is fine, but I found levelling and customising new heroes to be quite overwhelming on top of everything else. That, plus the research trees and hero skill trees leave a lot to be desired. It's fun to get stuck into a game or two on this, but after that I was done with the game. If you're desperate for a 4x game get this when it's on sale. It'll keep you occupied for a good few hours..

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Interesting game, and I like a lot of the ideas. The overall concept is solid, and it implements some brilliant improvements over similar games in places. I really want to like this game a lot more than I do.But... (and we all knew THAT was coming)The graphics are tolerable until you get to the hero units. Human models are Not Good. The clothing options feel like they must be at several inches thick in places.Depending on your chosen 'race', you will have resource shortfalls for a good long while. Also, heroes cost a fairly high amount of upkeep in gold... and when one is available to purchase, the game tends to not give you the option of NOT purchasing.The entire backstory and current story of the game setting feels a bit bland and unrefined.and the tech and skill trees are... how to put this... short. on. options.Overall, while the game is not strictly BAD, it is not nearly as good as the somewhat unfinished, glitchy Civilization 4 TCMod that came before it.I'm still likely to play this once in a while, but it's just going to send me scuttling back to Fall from Heaven 2. I'm recomending it though, since honestly, it's better than a lot of the alternatives OTHER than FfH2, which can be twitchy.

Posted: November 28, 2016
												As a big fan of 4X games, Fallen Enchantress is in my top 5 along with Civilization, Endless Legend and Master of Magic. The great thing is that alongside great empire building and warmongering, you have armies and heroes that you can send forth on epic quests - even to conquer a series of fabled lands with monsters that can rock the very foundation of the land.More often than not the other players in the game become mere footnotes in the stories that your heroes bring back; no more than annoyances when they fight for dominion while you are called to much more important quests. All in all a tremendously fun, highly replayable quest-enhanced fantasy empire building RPG.Highly recommended indeed.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												This is a passable Fantasy themed 4x game, but the thing that keeps bringing me back to it is the Adventure RPG aspects. The RPG elements are simple, but you really feel like every level matters. Equipping your heroes is engaging as well. The combat is ok, but I end up auto-resolving most encounters that I can get away with. I'm just here for the levels and perks and the badass Hero-filled Army stack tearing around the countryside on horseback wiping out monsters and opposing players alike while completing quests from learning about hygene from a time traveler to taking over the world by controlling all Dragons.FE:LH is a less swingy and more balanced version than the previous Elemental series games, but that lack of vareity in other places really lets me focus on what I like about it, running around raising mountains and wiping out ancient elemental creatures so I can post their heads in my cities.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												WARNING: This game requires a Stardock account to activate!-That said, i THINK that I will enjoy the game. So far, I've only played the tutorial. I'll come back and do a more complete review later, after playing more, but I wanted to get the warning out to those who (like me) don't like to have to set up seperate accounts (and the resulting junk mail) in order to play the game. Other reviews have compared this to Master of Magic (MOM), the Civ games, and even to Heroes of M&M. It IS most like MOM and the early Civ games. There are cities to build, and stuff to research, and armies to send out to explore and conquer. Those armies can (as with MOM) include Champions. So that is similar to Heroes 4. And there are some "quests" the completion of which is important to increase your fame. Fame is important because (as in MOM) the more famous you are the more and better champions you attract.Combat is turn-based on square tiles, but the tiles only affect movement. Spells and arrows can be cast/shot in any direction. and you can attack on a 45 degree angle. (Unlike the rediculous combat on the new "M&M" 10. But don't get me going on that!)-In sumary, if you have played MOM, after a few controll adjustments, you will be able to play FE:LH. And if you miss the Halcyon days Of Microsoft (MOM, and Master of Orion 1 and 2) and 3DO (Might and Magic 1-9, and Heroes 1-4) they are available on Great old Games (GOG.com) and often go on sale for 2 or 3 bucks. They work through a DOS window so they will work on almost any modern computer.I think FE:LH will have some of that old magic to it. So, in spite of the whole Stardock account thing, I'm glad i bought it.Update: I've played through one game and it was enjoyable. And the game-play does fall somewhere between MOM and Civ II. It won't ever make  a list of MY Most Favorite Games. But it is one that I will go back to from time to time. A worthwhile addition to any Strategy Gamer's collection.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												TL/DR: Avoid the game, there are better ones of the same genre.I am a sucker for 4x fantasy games, and I really want to like the Fallen Enchantress.  It mixes strategy and RPG elements.  But the bugs and deal breakers really make this game not a good one.  A real shame. Border of influence will not show, need to restart game. Memory leaks, after loading games multiple times, it will lag then stops working.  Need to restart game after loading saves 2-3 times. Forces the camera to focus on a certain city, so if there is a message of some outpost is destroyed, then click show me, it wont, because it will focus on the city at the start of your turn. AI casted grip of winter to one of my city, it disables the build button on ALL of my cities.  I tried to restart the game, still the same.  I checked their in-game encyclopedia, the tooltip says, "stops production to the target players cities", so I think it is a global spell. Because it affected all of my cities.  Waited many turns, thinking it is not permanent, found out on my own it is a bug, that I need to remove the spell from my cities. Bad designs of buttons, click build here, click build here again.  Click somewhere else mistakenly, build screen will disappear. Mechanics are interesting, but in-game help is no help at all. Horrible implementation. You wont know what spells are casted againts you, unless the AI says so, the notification is sometimes hidden or not prevalent.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												First of all, I have to stay that Stardock is great and fair company. I bought Elemental back in the day and that game wasn't too good. They acknoledged that and gave me first Fallen Enchantress and this game for free. I didn't expect or ask them to do that either.Now about this game. It has certainly improved somewhat from the previous iterations, but the core problems still remain. Basically, it's trying to be a Civ type strategy game and a some sort of light RPG at the same time and fails at both because of this. For the kingdom level strategy I feel the detail level is too high. You'll have to research everything from daggers and small shields to 2-h swords and plate mail one small step at the time. There is a choice of dozens of buildings to construct in the cities, many of which should be abstracted, IMO. It's fine to equip the heroes in detail, but same detail in regular unit building bogs it down. Of course one can just use the default units so it's not the biggest problem.Speaking of equipping heroes, how can I build a squad of longbowmen that doesn't cost money to build, but when I want to equip one of my heroes with a longbow, I have to pay for it... a lot. There's a disconnect between the startegy "layer" and RPG one there. Should be that conventional equipment for heroes is available for free as long as I have the tech for it, but enchanted equipment must be bought, found or crafted.Correct me if I'm wrong, but I'm under impression that Stardock had bought the rights for Master of Magic, but decided to make Elemental instead. That's a shame because I think it would have been great success with but slight modernization. This game would be better if it was more like MOM. Still, I find myself playing in sessions of hour or two so it's not all bad.Getting better, but can't recommend it at least yet. Sorry Stardock.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I enjoyed this game immensely, and I would recommend it to anyone that really enjoys a good strategy game with a heroic element to it.I got attached to my heroes, my cities, and my troops on my first play through.  So much so that I created an entire nation in the likeness of past roleplaying experiences and all of my heroes were a part of that nation, personalized colors, banners, and all.  This aspect of the game gives it extra replayability, since each nation can have its strengths and weaknesses, along with its heroes perfections and flaws.  Combine that with the ability to build a city however you see fit, be it a fortress on the bay, a river side village tilling gold, or a forest enclave where the wisest of the sages study the elements to provide your civilization with insurmountable power, the options are endless.When you're not at war, your heroes can adventure across the country side fighting bandits, banshees, giants and mystical creatures, all while uncovering secrets of ages past that make your empire even more powerful.  In time as your power grows, your heroes can lead their armies into epic battles against the fiercest of dragons in the depths of boneyards teeming with the souls of the tortured, fighting to control the worlds remaining population of dragons.The idea that you can make this game whatever you want makes it so worth while.  If you're in it for a quick match, go for it.  If you're like me and like to get in-depth with your games and truly take your time while enjoying every aspect the game has to offer, you're also in for a real treat.  You could easily sink hundreds of hours into this game, depending on the bounds of your imagination.Do I recommend this game?  Wholeheartedly.  If you enjoy gearing your heroes and your armies in an RPG fashion, a solid strategic experience, as well as a beautiful visual experience, I wouldn't wait any longer.

content:
Posted: January 28
												Ok, outline review and then I'll get to my main complaints. -The tutorial was lacking. For example, it glossed over how yields work in this game and explained with concepts foreign to a first time player(what is essence?). Most of it was in video format which was a waste of time when I could've just read one or two lines to understand. -Graphics are not my style at all. Black outline around everything. Cartoony (which i dont mind) yet ugly. -Lots of unit customization which I've recently started enjoying from other games like Endless Legend and AoW3. Except I still usually prefer Civ style units that all fill a niche. If you like customization then you will love it in this game.-I heard multiplayer crashes alot. - Mostly combat based game. Diplomacy is lacking, rather than strategicly choosing city locations it's about getting lucky with finding good tile yields.-Combat is mostly simplistic. Think of heroes of might and magic or a japanese SRPG. Does not account for facing. melee units try to gang up on units, ranged stays away. includes a turn order bar. I prefer AoW3 for this. -The magic system is (again) comparable to the heroes series or age of wonders.  upkeeps, strategical map spells as well as combat spells. -You can make OP imba builds. AFAIK, the AI can't. -As usual the AI cheats at higher levels. Not complaining. How would you make a superhuman chess algorithm with a thousand more variables and with gameplay mechanics that were constantly adjusted through patches? As long as its passable. - Quests are randomly placed but chosen from a small pregenerated pool. These are a neat fluff to accompany the constant combat but you start seeing the same ones again really quickly. The writing isn't too shabby.The UI *SUCKS*. The load button is hidden behind 4 keystrokes. There are no screens showing data for all cities at once. want to see unrest? you have to open click them individually and hunt for the stat. Did you just level up or get a new hero? You're not allowed to minimize the selection screen to check what else you have. With auto end turn enabled, the game will execute commands  you queued on other armies even though you need to make an adjustment. Without auto end turn, the game lacks clear notifications. Oh, it has some but its certainly not clear. Where is the hotkeys list? Gotta look that up online. On that topic, this game actually has a convenient quick save button unlike a lot of other 4X games. In game manual lacks a search function but at least its alphabetically ordered. I want to say that the game isn't too shabby... except it is. It's not for me but I know there are people out there who would enjoy this. Recommended for people who want a customizable, combat based, fantasy themed 4X. Just check out the other games I mentioned in my review first ;-)

												An outstanding strategy game that gives you a world and lets you imagine. This game has a lot of imaginative features and it really feels like you're creating a new custom empire each time you play through a game. So if you're looking for replayability I can definitely say that this is something worth looking at. The combat for the game could be improved some. 												While the hex based tiles led me to think that the game mechanics might resemble Civ, I'd say FE: LH is a closer cousin to HOMM, which is not necessarily a bad thing.  The game gets you focused on leveling up and equiping the units in your party so that you can fight stronger enemies.  It's a fun game, but I can't help but think that perhaps it might have benefitted from having a campaign format like HOMM.  Dynamic maps seem better suited to games that focus more on territories and cities.It has an impressive tech tree, and I think this is where it really stands out.  Every technology looks meaningful and you really do get a sense of progression.  I do recommend on picking a slower progression setting because the normal setting seems too quick.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												When it comes to turn-based strategy and empire-building, Fallen Enchantress really is a dream come true in some respects. It's a welcome change of pace from traditional worlds and strategy games that we've become all too familiar with. Sure, it's cool playing as Nobunaga in the next "Conquer Japan" strategy game... and it's fun playing around in the Civilization series. But what I love about Fallen Enchantress is that it's a fresh world with unique characters that we don't know anything about right off the bat. The game has it's own unique flavor and the ability to customize many aspects of the game to your liking. All of these are fantastic aspects to this game. However, it is not without some understandable criticism.While it appears simple, it is a game you can easily get frustrated with. Sometimes straight up bad luck can screw players from the get-go. This can even begin with just where you start on a map in a new scenario game. You can be blessed with starting in a very sound strategic location... or you can start in an area where expansion can be a total nightmare (for example, between an ocean, 20 tiles of barren wasteland and no resources and a bunch of monster bases that can easily crush starting players). This is a common criticism I have with other strategy games due to this common pitfall (from a design standpoint) is when too many things are influenced by luck (or sheer randomness, to be precise). Strategy games should be about tactics, placement and preparation. And Fallen Enchantress rewards it and punishes those that just blunder about randomly. Which is great. In that way, it's a strategy game. However, it can also feel like you are rewarded (or punished, more likely) on the roll of the dice. In *that* way, it's an unpredictable strategy game -- which can sometimes be fun and sometimes just be annoying.In the end, though... would I recommend Fallen Enchantress? Yes. It's a gem in its own right. I'd also recommend getting it on a deal, as I did.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												Do you like Civilization? Do you like RPG's? This is basically Civ where you can level up your leader like an RPG character, give them gear and talents, and let them go forth and do your bidding. Also there's questing, recruiting magical creatures or other heroes.You control various cities with an area of influence around them, and deal with managing cities by building structures, focusing on what the city produces, and doing research, as well as controlling natural resources on the map. There are wandering monsters (Think Barbarians in Civ) that pop up from time to time and they may attack a city if they are close enough.You can build armies of general sorts of units, but even this has flavor because you're not just designing them and naming them, you pick the equipment and gear they use, and you do have the ability to auto-upgrade existing units to whatever the newest armor/weapons that your research has unlocked, provided you have the resources.The real fun comes from heroes, who either are recruited during certain quests or random events, or seek you out to join you when you have accomplished enough to gain enough fame. Your Sovreign (your faction's leader) is a hero with talent trees with plenty of choices, spells, and gear just like any good RPG. They can be skilled up to be good at managing a city, good at leading an army, or good fighters in and of themselves (or anything in between really). The same goes for other heroes you come across.There is diplomacy with other empires but for the most part you're flying solo and trying to win on your own. There are numerous victory options, and most mirror the ones you'd find in Civ.The random events and quests are varied and interesting, and the randomly generated maps lead to a lot of replayability.The weakest aspects of the game are the city building (which, while it has depth, is nowhere near what you'd find in a dedicated city building game), the RPG aspects (while there's a lot to do and the random events are good, eventually you'll get some repeats after you've played a bunch of games). They are both pretty well done but not great - it is better than average at both but exceptional at neither. Additionally, there's not really ANY story or campaign mode. You have scenarios, but this is largely a sandbox with a randomly generated map and any story is going to be what you personally make of it via the random events that happen.HOWEVER: This game supports mod tools and user-created races, maps, items, quests, etc. Any variety the game lacks out of the box goes away if you poke around the official forums for a bit and find something that changes things you dislike (or make your own).In sum, this game is quite enjoyable and I find myself equally drawn in by both the empire building and RPG aspects of it. Neither aspect is 100% perfect, but the games can be long (especially if you play on enormous maps with lots of AI as I tend to), and if I get bored with the RPG aspect for a bit, I'll spend time focusing on just my cities for a bit. The game lets me play it however I want and never forces me to do anything, and there's enough to do that I consistently go back to it.It's been out for awhile now and you can probably pick it up at a decent price. The DLC is fine - it's not must-have and it's not a waste of money. It's mostly small things - new heroes, new quests, new items, which all randomly pop up in your game. The game is fun with them, but nothing stands out as  absolute must-haves. Get the DLC if you get the game and enjoy it and want more of it, or if you get the game bundled with it at a decent price.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												Being perfectly honest I have no idea how I ended up getting this game. Not sure if it was a gift, part of a pack of games I got for free on a random page or whatever, but it’s an actually quite interesting game. However as usual, I will start with the negative parts of it:You know, this game let’s you create your own race, heroes and♥♥♥♥♥♥WHICH IS QUITE COOL, however something I totally HATE is not being able to edit that race. The first time you make your own, you'll have NO IDEA WHAT YOU’RE DOING, so being able to test it out and change what doesn’t work out should be a pretty normal thing to have. But no, the option isn’t there, which is disappointing.Something that I also don’t quite like is how passive the AI always seems to be. If you don’t play in really high difficulty matches, it always seems that it’s me the one being an #sshole and invading others, as they never seem to make a move. And when they finally do, it’s some sort of suicidal attack that’s as pointless as a submarine on Mars.Lastly, the game has a feature of not letting heroes die, but instead damaging them permanently. It’s a system I like, however if a hero gets killed by the last damn enemy, doesn’t matter how many heads he bashed into the ground, not only he doesn’t get ANY EXPERIENCE but he also gets injured for life. That’s bullsh#t. At least give him less XP, but not NO XP AT ALL!However, ignoring the negative stuff, what do we have left? A weird mix between Civilizations and Final Fantasy Tactics… Of all things. Yeah, it’s a weird f#cking mix but it actually works quite well.As I’ve said before, you create your own race and play against custom or default other races in open maps, what sets this game apart from other Civ clones however, is the RPG style it has. There are items, quests and monsters out there, and your heroes level up and get quite powerful as they grow.The game also has a unit creator tool, quite basic but it gives you the choice of setting your own troops by default, as expensive and game-breaking as you see fit. It’s quite fun… But since enemies won’t use it, their troops usually never catch on to you.Maps usually also have some story and mayor quests going on, something that I totally like. And since most players on the map will want to clear those out, it adds to the competitive nature of these kind of games.Is it a good game? Yeah, it is. However it seems to be kinda obscure and not well known. I would recommend it for any Civilizations fan who wants to try something new, although as usual, on a good sale.TL;DR Edition: Civilizations mixed with RPG and turn-based elements. A good mix, with a few problems that are easy to overlook. Good for fans of strategy games, and a solid purchase on a sale.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Honestly, I don't know how to rate this game. So in this review I'm going to talk myself through formulating a rating, and maybe you'll see why I am so confused by how to rate this game.- To start lets point this out. This game is HORRIBLY optimized. I averaged 40 FPS as low as 20 and I have a beast rig. But I averaged these fps on EVERY graphical setting. Max, medium, and low. Did the devs even aim for 60fps? I guess not.+ These graphics are good enough for me, I enjoy them. But a lot of persons today may want something better. The game was released in 2012 though. We didn't have any Witcher 3 graphics back then, remember?+/- The sounds were decent, but nothing to write home about.+ The game has a story mode with two scenarios. One is essentially a "Squad-based" campaign where you mostly use "hero" units to accomplish quests. The second plays essentially like the main "skirmish"-esque game mode plays (Which is called "new game" and that's it), except with some added story that keeps it far more interesting than the regular skirmish mode.- The repetition in the game is....ugh. Its the same quests over and over again. If you play "new game" first, you'll never enjoy the story mode because you've already done everything you can do in the story mode for 9 hours at least beforehand. If you do story mode first you'll never appreciate "new game"due to its lacking of the main story content that kept the scenarios interesting. The game's formula grows old after 5 hours.+/- The turn based combat is something unique for this game in the 4X scene. It keeps the game very interesting, an even a little hard in the beginning. Eventually you learn the perfect strategy for each map because honestly, it doesn't have many. Then it just becomes a chore, and since auto-resolve tends to favor you anyway, you tend to skip the feature entirely. It's good...but becomes bad.So I still am lost about what to give this game. Honestly, the game has a very mediocre feel in every aspect of it. From the studio that made so many good RTS games, you'd think they'd be able to get a turn based game down pretty easily. But honestly, I'm going to have to give the game a 5/10. It was fun, eventually the repetition and lack of optimization got to me. (Eventually being 5 hours in. Its amazing that I made it to nearly 20 hours). It's a very AVERAGE game with some very poor design decisions. Mostly bug-free though.So do I recommend it? Well.....no. It was more of a chore than it was fun to play. So even if it was fun for a little bit. Well...It's really just not worth your money, ok? Please save yourself the  headache that this game induces and just avoid it.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This game has some advantages and disadvantages to a similar title with a lot more polish: Endless Legends. I thought I'd compare the two.Advantages to Fallen Enchantress:+ You can rotate the map, which is nice in tactical mode (during battles).+ The quests you get have less variety compared to Endless Legends, but in Enchantress they invariably involve combat of some kind, which is good for people who like combat. Also, there are sometimes branching paths in quests, a concept pretty much unheard of in Endless.+ The fantasy setting is great if you like that kind of thing. I do, and it's the biggest reason to like this game imho. Endless Legends has this strange cyberpunk/fantasy hybrid thing going on which rarely makes sense.+ Huge customization. You can create your empire or kingdom from scratch, rather than the civ standby of picking from the list of pre-made leaders. You can pick and choose bonuses (and penalties) to fit your playstyle, as well as having full control over the color palette that will appear on your units and cities. While equipping units is done in Endless Legends as well as Fallen Enchantress, Enchantress has a tad more variety in the early game and also has the advantage that your units change their appearance with their gear, a feature Endless lacks.Disadvantages to Fallen Enchantress:- The maps. City placement is restricted to fixed locations, and battles play out in an instanced flat plane with no variety. In Endless Legends you can build wherever the hell you want like a normal civ game and when two stacks of units fight, the overall game pauses and the units spread out into the surrounding tiles, to duke it out for six rounds. This means that units are affected by terrain and elevation, and it also means battles can be stalemates or attrition fights rather than the forced fight to the death in Enchantress.- Diplomacy is wonkier than Civ. When I played, I regularly had enemy civs offer me money out of the blue. There's a demand tribute button on the diplomacy screen, but there's also a give tribute button which will automagically give the recieving player 10% of your gold income for 30 turns. If your arbitrary point total (if you played any recent Civ game you know what I mean) is above a certain point, your opponents will shower you in gifst in the hope that you attack them last. It's funny at first, until you realize that ten percent of their income is almost always nothing and it's a completely hollow gesture in the first place. If you accept tribute from them, it gives the other civ a negative diplomacy moodlet becaude 'you demanded tribute from them'. Which, ironically, makes them more afraid you'll attack them and more likely to give tribute in the future. Also worth noting is treaties and trade are separate options in this game and that treaties must be picked one at a time, so you can't do things like sign borders agreements or take cities in exchange for peace. You either mutually accept peace (with a possible bribe in gold if needed), or you surrender everything and quit the game. There is no other way to end a war prematurely.- No navy. The sea (and air) are sorely lacking in Fallen Enchantress. Any lakes you encounter (and you will) are impassible voids. This is a shame, because a heavy focus into earth magic (if you're lucky enough to randomly generate a champion unit that knows some) eventually nets you the ability to terraform the land around you. You can turn sea into land, land into settleable land or hills, hills to mountains and vice versa. The problem is that, as mentioned, terrain has no impact on combat and cities don't work neighboring tiles, so there's very little motivation to actually do this.- The minimalistic approach. Numbers in this game are very small. You'll spend ten turns on a building that nets you +1 science per turn. Every customization option in this game, from making units to leveling champions to constructing buildings to upgrading them to using spells in or out of combat to making your empire in the first place, all of them are minimalistic tweaks. Despite all the options you have, none of it actually does much of anything. You might see a building that generates double the science that your city already produced, until you realize you built every science building available and you're only producing seven, and that building replaces another one which already increased your science output by 75% so instead of netting +7 science for your twenty turns of production, you're actually only getting +1. Your units will get damage buffs of 10 to 20 percent at a time, but that translates into 1-2 extra damage on your attack, which won't make a difference to the vast majority of enemies. Whenther they had the buff or not it'll still take the same amout of attacks, same number of turns in combat, to kill anything. The result is that the game feels very hollow, where it looks on the surface like there's a lot of replay value but there actually isn't. Seeing as replay value is the ultimate goal for a 4x game, this is a serious shortcoming.Summary:If you just rewatched Game of Thrones and you REALLY want to play a Civ game that uses a fantasy setting and magic and whatnot, if you want to play dress-up with your units and if you really don't care if the game is actually any good, you might as well play Fallen Enchantress. But if what you're looking for is a 4x game with any level of depth, a game that will entertain you for more than a few hours and a game where your choices have a drastic impact on the flow of the game, go for Endless Legends.Oh, and Legends has multiplayer, for the people who care about that.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												Pros: Great PotentialEasy to ModNice Improvements over original Fallen EnchantressPretty visualsAllows for nearly likitless creativityCons: Extremely Buggy!!Versions 1.0-1.6 had game ending bugs if you leveled a character beyond available perk choicesVersion 1.8 is a game ending bug at start that prevents you from ever having more than one Fame point, effectively eliminating heroes from the entire gameDevs seem to have taken a nearly bugless game (Fallen Enchantress v1.32) and with only a few minor changes made it entirely unplayable for many of us.Devs remain entirely unresponsive to players who report these bugs, and seem to have no interest in fixing themHave been waiting for fixes for years now, sending report after report with god knows how much information, and all I've seen are some slight A.I improvements, a couple optimizations, and a bunch of expensive DLC's that could've been made by any of the more capable modders out there.Other thoughts:FE 1 was completely fixed as of 1.32, but LH is a train wreck after eight major overhauls, roughly 50 minor patches, and still the devs are focusing on increasingly derivative DLC's? No sale discount is enough to make this worth the money, even after a couple years of "updates."Fallen Enchantress was a great game. If Legendary Heroes looks fun to you, buy its predecessor instead; LH is just an endless pit for you to throw your money in.10/10 for potential-10/10 for bugs and greedy devs0/10 overall

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
												I've been part of the Elemental odyssey since the early days of the paid beta for War of Magic.  As we all know by now, Elementa: War of Magic arrived in a pretty bad state and never recovered from its severe design deficiencies.  Stardock, being Stardock, refused to abandon their dream of a great new 4X fantasy game and released a stand-alone expansion, Fallen Enchantress, that tried to rectify what went wrong with the first game by cutting out lots of features of the original that just didn't work, and by enhancing what was left.  When all was said and done, while Fallen Enchantress was a marked improvement over EWoM, it still struck me as a mediocre game.When Legendary Heroes was added to my account (I was one of those who were 'comped' with two free expansions) , I was not in any rush to try it.  I mean, seeing how FE was still nothing that great, I figured LH was going to be just another incremental improvement on the base game.  I WAS WRONG!Legendary Heroes has completely amazed me with its gameplay (especially with the recent 1.4 patch).  Finally, we have an Elemental game that lives up to the hopes and dreams we all had when Elemental was first announced!  This is now a fantastic fantasy-based 4X experience with lots of faction/hero customization options that really adds a great RPG element, as well as a smart implementation of the core 4X (explore, expand, exploit, and exterminate) gameplay dynamic.  The tactial battles, which were a bit bland before, are now fun and challenging endeavors (the tactical AI is very good!).  City building, which was also rather boring in the previous iterations of the series, has received a lot of love, amking it a quite enjoyable to watch your cities grow.  Questing has also received some nice attention, making for some interesting one-off battles.  Add in some "game changing" random events (something Stardock is known for), and you now have a very addictive, very polished experienced.Stardock has also just begun releasing DLC for the game.  While I have only purchased the Quest DLC so far - it seems to offer the most bang for the buck at the moment - I suspect we can expect a lot more that should really enhance the game even more.  Lastly, this being a proper PC game, there are some great mods already available.Long short: Legendary Heroes is a very good 4X fantasy game that is well worth your gaming dollar.  I don't think it is too much of a stretch to say that with some more DLC and/or an expansion, Legendary Heroes could well match the revered status of Stardock's sci-fi  magnum opus, Galactic Civilizations II.

content:
Posted: March 9
												Ambitious game that was fairly fun and injured by unfulfilled promise. If you are really jonesing for a 4x fix, you might try it. It tries to be Master of Magic and does a fair job. Not as quite up to that bar, but mostly enjoyable. Otherwise, you probably want to give it a miss.Decent music; Remeniscent of Babylon 5. Graphics system is pretty nifty, but the assets are lackluster. Could have looked great, yet didn't.Gameplay had a bunch of neat ideas but felt unfinished. The characters level slowly (which is fine) but the benefits of a level accumulate slowly, as well. Not horrid, but not great. Cities have map-based assets, which was cool, but weird limits on how and where resources can be to use them.The biggest deficit was the engine's crazy slow loading for everything. Sometimes, that crashed it. Sometimes, you really did just need to wait a few minutes to see something. This became quite frustrating. I do not like waiting multiple minutes on a turn end and 15-20 seconds to get a response on a button press to open a menu. Felt like a memory leak somewhere was probably at fault, but certainly it slowed down by the end game. The game seems to assume you won't have more than ten or so cities, since the UI gets really cumbersome at that point.If the game was fast and responsive the whole time, the other deficits would probably be less detrimental to the effect.

												A true gem of a game.  Why is is great?  well it has a lot of things going for it, but there's one feature that really stands out: customizeable units.  Tired of generic knights in shining armor?  Put some ladies on giant wolves instead (Wargs are OP).  don't have enough iron to build more high tier units?  design a unit that uses the recources you do have. I keep wishing other stratagy games would add in this sort of feature, because it turns an already solid game into a masterpeice.  The story is pretty underdevloped (not as bad as some other stardoc games, but it could be a lot better), but i barely even noticed.  Graphics are dated, but if that doesn't turn you off, you will love this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25
												This 4x (eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, eXterminate) fantasy strategy game does many things right, but also has some bugs/issues.+ Highly customizable heroes and standart units. From their looks, to their weapons, armor and equipment. You can even change the background of their picture to your liking. This way even the most regular game units can look unique.+ Nice and interesting selection of units, each with their own traits and skills. From weak wolves to the almighty dragons, every one is made with passion for detail.+ Intelligent bulding queue. When you had your town producing currency for example and you decide to add an actual unit or building to the queue, the town will properly priorize the later and put it in front of the infinite currency production.+ Instead of just having you fight enemies for rewards the game uses well-written sidequests. In some of them you even get to make a desicion - which affects the outcome.- Unlike the sidequests, the main story mode barely has any story worth mentioning. One map, some general directions about where to go next every 20 hours or so and a few lines once you reach the goal. The end.- Loading times are surprisingly long, compared to most other games. Usually if you load or reload a game after a bad decision, you are back in a couple of seconds. Here it takes up to one minute.- Loading causes your units to continue on their planned way even if you hadn't hit the move button when you saved. Saving after you have selected to go to an enemy in the distance will have them run all the way to the enemy by themselves when you load, engaging him in a fight. Even if you found out that it was a poor decision. I mean, you can still cancel the fight. But you will have to walk back again, which leaves you exposed to the enemy.-  The game uses "influence zones" that show the area you and your allies/enemies control. Most of the time, that is. Sometimes it won't show the zones at all.Compared to similar other games like my favourite "Age of Wonders", Fallen Enchantress: Legendary heroes features less main story and less strategy options (no cover system from ranged attack units/spells, no option to engage an enemy army with multiple armies from different sides) while offering a better selection of side quests. I know that the later Age of Wonders games included repeatable "missions", but they didn't have much of a story.Fallen Enchantress equals even some full-fledged roleplaying games in that aspect. Collect spider webs, find lost stuff, save villages, hand-feed out of control monsters to tame them... just to name some of them.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												Verdict: This is the 4x game I always wanted. A grand turn-based strategy game, comparable to Civilization IV but in a gorgeous high-fantasy setting with tactical battles and RPG elements. Most significantly for me, it is fully customisable: design your own faction, leader and units to suit your personal playstyle and role-play. Longer games have stability issues, but I fixed mine by turning off anti-aliasing. 8/10Story: It may be misleading to speak of story in a game like this, and I have not yet played the campaign scenario. The premise of the world, elaborated here from previous Elemental games, is interesting enough. And the customisation allows you to create your own story as you please. 6/10Gameplay:  Despite some AI and balance issues, the gameplay is solid and very engaging. It’s not long before that classic Civilization “one more turn” syndrome sets in and takes over, and single games can easily steal away 20-30 hours. Though the fashion in 4x strategy is towards hexagons, square-based maps do the job here, and it is fun to explore rich landscapes dense with monsters, treasure and quests to fulfill. City and resource management are interesting, and it’s satisfying to see your metropolises grow and your empire expand. Research is broken into three tech trees (Civic, Warfare, Magic) you advance separately, making it a strategic choice of where your focus will be. Tactical battles are fun, if a bit on the simple side; tactics emerge solely from your unit design and the composition of your armies, without regard for other factors such as terrain. Auto-resolve can be a bit wonky, and can sometimes beat otherwise unwinnable battles, but it is not game-breaking. The UI is a masterpiece and provides all the information you need to manage your empire. Detailed faction and unit customisation are what tie all these factors together and make Fallen Enchantress a superior experience to similar 4x games.  9/10Graphics: The graphics will appear a bit dated to some, but the art style fits the unique setting nicely resulting in a somewhat cartoony, but still beautiful, dark and broken world. 7/10Sound/Music: The sound is not exceptional (ambiance is decent), but the music is great with some truly epic themes to conquer to.  7/10

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												There was a previous incarnation or two of this game and this one plays in a similiar vein to the previous versions.  Set up a "colonly", build a few buildings and expland your territory.  There is a party adventure mode as well that lets you explore your world, upgrade your adventurers, and collect items to equip them with.  The campaign could use some work though... a bit more depth, cut scenese, voice overs, ect.  But really I bought this game for the map editor and sandbox mode.  After awhile (40 hours) it does tend to get repetative.  That said I was intrigued enough to play each sandbox custome game to see each individual ending related to that vicotry condition.  If there was a way to infuse "more story" into the game it'd be a real gem.  The only knock against this game is if you play the "huge" map setting.  I have an advanced gaming rig that starts to chug and eventually crash if the world is overly populated with cites.An 8 out of 10.  If the developers would add cutscences and some RPG elements it could easily climb to a 10 out 10.  The expansion packs seem focused towards "new loot" and different AI characters to play against.  They don't really add very much to the gaming experiance so only buy them if you have a couple extra bucks collecting dust.

												First, the tutorial videos is utterly useless (to build, click the build button, then the building wanted). What do all those numbers, statuts, data, do ? Just a tiny description. Nothing is told about long-term strategy... in a strategy game.What about the lore ? Since it's fantasy, it's must be important, right ? Not here. The story is so cliche, the factions are so cliches and nothing is really polished. Everything you find/read about lore will make you say "meh, classic". I'm not about what's typical, but it's not even linked in a good way. Just a bunch of random typical stuff. And nothing is really used in the game anyway. You can totally skip it and you will miss nothing of the game (for those who may ask, I consider lore in assassin's creed, total war or dark souls important, so you have my point of view).And here comes my main complain : this game has no identity at all. I felt like playing a mod where the creator just replaced everything with fantasy elements. If it were a mod, it would be good enough. But it's not a mod. There is a hole team behind it. If it were a film, it would be one of those stupid fantasy films pre-LotR made by people who understand nothing about fantasy, but did it anyway because "it's fantasy. Kinds like it, we will attract them and make money".

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												As much as I love the game concepts in FE:LH, I simply cannot recommend it because the way the developers implemented these concepts is (to me, anyway) very shallow and frustrating. It does offer a little fun, but barely enough for even the sale price of $9.99 to feel worth it (and certainly not for full price). I'll elaborate in greater detail below. This review is based upon my time playing the game during this free-to-play weekend, though I previously played over 100 hours (not on steam) in Elemental and also tried out the free copy of the first FE Stardock gave me (but it didn't keep my interest very long at all). Here is a list of my main frustrations:-For a game called "Legendary Heroes", you barely get any heroes to play with;-Even worse, the leveling system for the heroes you do get doesn't do them any justice;-Creation of custom Sovereigns and Races sounds cool, but the choices are very few and really offer little strategic/tactical impact;-This is also true for creating custom troops - equipment choices in particular are painfully limited and mostly irrelevant;-Consequently, tactical battles lack any real depth - not to mention the many other issues with them (no troop placement phase, inconsistent battle map sizes, etc);-Overall, these frustrations result in a negative gameplay experience for me, to the point where even the interesting environments, quests to complete, and wild monsters to fight just cannot keep me invested in playing. I love the concepts so very much, but their implementation kills the potential fun. Read on for a more detailed look at these issues:Not Enough HeroesYou can only recruit a new hero when you reach certain levels of "fame", which you get from completing quests from random locations spawned on the map. Each new level requires even more fame, such that in my 12 hours of free playing I had only gotten a mere 2 heroes. This is simply unacceptable for a game called "Legendary Heroes" and it seriously undermines the RPG aspect of play. Furthermore, when you unlock a new hero you are only offered a choice between 2 candidates. The first time, both were at level 1, which meant I got to choose my first hero's class when she reached level 2 (I went with Defender, as my Sovereign was a Warlock); but when I finally unlocked my second choice of heroes, both candidates were past level 2, meaning that I was stuck with the classes already assigned to them (either another Defender or another Warlock...while I wanted to pick another class I didn't have yet). This was extremely frustrating and not at all fun. Hero Leveling is a DisappointmentEvery time a hero gains a level, they get 1 point to spend on a new perk (including passive buffs and active abilities). All heroes have a few General perks available, while the majority are based on their class (Defender, Assassin, etc). The first problem is that 1 skill point per level is not enough to give you a decent selection. Want them to unlock the next 3 spells in the type of magic they know? There goes your point. Want them to learn first aid? Their goes your point. And levels require a lot of fighting to get. Limited skill points wouldn't be so bad if the perks actually made a big difference, but most of them don't. For my Defender, some perks added only +5 HP (or the like), while a few offered new combat moves. Sadly, the layout of the skill tree meant I needed to pick many lame perks before reaching the ones that actually sounded useful, so in my 12 hours of play I never unlocked any cool ones for my heroes. I realize the devs may not want heroes to be overpowered (although there are so few of them in numbers that I feel they almost *should* be a bit OP), but you can do that by giving a level progression to the cool abilities so they start off weak and can be improved with further perks, not by making it very slow and frustrating to even unlock the abilities at all. Anyway, the leveling system is very frustrating and kills the fun for me. Custom Sovereign/Faction/Unit Creation is ShallowCustomization is one of my favorite aspects in a game, in both the practical and aesthetic senses (custom ship design from Gal Civ II is a great example). This game appears to offer these features, but once you dig in they are really very shallow. While there are nuances between the 3 types of custom creation, all three share the same flaws: too few deign points, too few design options (in particular for "weaknesses" that let you take a hit in one area to gain more design points to enhance another area), and the options they do have ultimately don't create a different feeling or play-style. This undermines not only the RPG aspect of the game, but also replayability (since no faction can really get that substantively different from another). I could go much more deeply into the details and nuances of/between types of customization, but in the end I still find each kind limiting and strategically/tactically unfulfilling. It's very disappointing and undercuts my motivation for playing the game. Poor Tactical BattlesEven by the most simple standards for a tactical battle system, the game comes up short. There are few weapons to choose from for your units (on top of their already shallow customization), and the attempt to make each class of weapon have more uniqueness fails. Giving some armor penetration to spears and a knockdown chance to hammers doesn't cut it. It makes designing units really boring, and tactical combat boring and repetitive as well. Ultimately, it just comes down to attack and defense values to decide the outcome, plus just not being stupid by letting the enemy gang up on your units (while you try to gang up on theirs). Also, having a maximum army size of just 9 units really limits not only the tactical possibilities (for example, I don't have enough units to, say, shield my custom Race's unmatched archers behind a line of heavy pikemen, nor does the customization system let me even make the Race of unmatched archers...), but also the sense of epic scale - you only ever fight skirmish-sized battles or send your small party against one super monster and its several minions. Anyway, the battles lose their appeal very quickly. ConclusionThe above frustrations are what ruin my playing experience for FE:LH; hence, I cannot recommend it. There are even other issues I didn't touch on (like the tech tree structure, etc) that I could maybe forgive on their own, but for a game called Legendary Heroes these key flaws regarding heroes/customization/battles are simply too much. Even though I will somewhat miss the match I sank 12 hours into during this free-to-play weekend, it's not even worth $9.99 to me to get the game and continue playing what I started. Sadly, I know that continuing it would entail more frustration with the game design than fun.If you care more about other aspects of the game, maybe you will still like it; but since many people (like me) might want to buy this because of the elements that are lacking (the promise of customization, RPG aspcets, battles), I want to call out those elements as I see them.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												At first glance, this looks like a pretty nifty cross of Civilization and Heroes of Might and Magic. And the idea really has potential, especially with the option to customize one's starting hero/civilization for a freeform game a lot like in Galactic Civilizations.Unfortunately, a great idea alone does not a great game make. In fact, I can't help but feel the idea is exactly what turns this game into a bit of a mess, because rolling CIV and HoMM into one simply does not work. I mean, the early game in CIV is all super-slow city development and tech research, whereas HoMM is all about having your heroes go out and do stuff from day one. That's a pretty huge gap in concept and Fallen Enchantress completely fails to bridge it. City development and tech start at a CIV-like glacial pace, but you're left feeling you're supposed to do stuff with your hero like in HoMM (being basically told so if you play a campaign).Admittedly, it almost works. Usually, the first couple of easy fights and mini quests give you a sense of progress. And then, things go downhill in a hurry because you run into your first fight highlighting how poorly balanced combat in this game is. I kid you not, based solely on the random placement of units on the map and luck with initiative, I have been completely wiped out and won without a scratch in the very same fight. Strategy and tactics my♥♥♥♥♥I'm really disappointed because I love the idea, but I'll go back to CIV and HoMM. Even the worst installments of those franchises never managed to drain my enthusiasm the way this game did, mostly because no CIV was this unbalanced (that's saying something!) and no HoMM featured fights this impossible early in campaigns unless impossible difficulty was exactly what it said on the tin.

												Well then, what a shiny little supprise this was, at first I was kind of sceptical that it would just be another civ/age of type clone with good gameplay for a short time then off to gather dust. Most entertaining it is, civ like, yet with rpg toon developement aspects, good city progress and tons more inside here if you care to delve deeper, complete customization of characters/factions and troops, plenty of equipment to make/buy/find for toons and skills and talent tree's, plus troops can upgrade and equip new stuff as well. Very impressed, so impressed I bought all the dlc for which is a shocker for me as I get bored real quick without any decent content or story to keep me going, all in all a most excellent game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												I love this game! It still has a bug every now and then but nothing that hurts the experience for me. My favorite part about it is being able to create your own factions and heroes (backstories and all) and play them. There is definitely a bit of a learning curve, but it's a fun learning curve. I've put quite a few hours in and I feel like I've barely scratched the surface of how many different strategic options there are. One of the major aspects that I love about this game is that it's not just a numbers game. Some games like this, for example Might and Magic VI, have a lot of strategic depth, but in the end it just becomes a numbers game as to who has the bigger army. This game does a really good job of balancing that out by limiting the size of each army, so you have to be more picky about what types of units make up your army, sort of like a mix between XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Might and Magic VI.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												So far the best fantasy 4x game I played  recently. I enjoyed the orginal and months playing with the expansion pack I dont think I played a fantasy 4x that can top it. I tried the new Eador  couldnt get into it. It felt stale.  Warlock 1 with all its expansion packs. Looked pretty but the economy was too simplistic for me. Age of Wonders 3 had flashy graphics and a cool turn based combat system but again the economy and city buidling was too simplistic. When it comes to Fallen Enchantress with Legendary Heroes it had the depthness I craved. I love the research tree, the magic system, the scarcity of resources, city management, and my favorite the turn based battles. The game is not pretty thats why I tried the flashier graphic games but I always came back to FE:LH. The mods you can download makes the game play even more vast. I enjoy the side quests, leveling your heroes, attracting heroes, and of course the variety of tactics with magic your heroes can issue forth. I love to upgrade my heroes with armor and mounts. The main game I almost bought that I wanted to try was Endlesss Legend. I was disapointed with Endlesss Space so it kind of burn me out from tryin Endlesss legends. Also I heard there was no tactical combat which is must for me in a fantasy 4x game. Makes it hard for me to go back to civ 5. I tried the classic turn based games like Heroes of Might and Magic 3 and Masters of Magic. The interfaces are probably too old for me now to fully appreciate its significants. From what I can tell this game is very comparable to what people loved about those games back then. I am not turn off by graphics cause my favorite games recently are Baldur's gate series, Alpha Centari, MOO2, and the orginal Fallout's but interface in older games can take awhile for me to get use too. Regardless I love this game and recommend it. I know some people hate it for variety of reasons but to me despite the graphics and generic story it is the Standard for Fantasy 4x right now. Hopefully they make a new one with better graphics, and a better story so the developers can get the respect they deserve.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I haven't played the previous entries in this series so I went in with not many preconceived ideas about what to expect.I know there were some issues with the earlier games, but Legendary Heroes is a very solid 4x title.There is a lot of diversity in the game in terms of unit design choices, heroes and city developement.Each playable faction is unique, and even though the differences seem subtle at first, this uniqueness becomes more apparent as the game progresses. There is a LOT to learn.Like most 4x games, it is a bit overwhelming at first, but it quickly grows on you and you settle in to get your empire up and running.There is a lot of challenge to be found in both the early and later game stages. Monsters roam the land and they range very widely in power between pushovers and godlike. Especially so for your weak early armies and champions. Knowing when to leave a challnge or quest for later is critical in keeping your troops and heroes safe.The AI is also actually decently competent. I lost one of my cities easily early on and got routed in my bid to take over an enemy city a few times.The strategic battles are one of my favorite parts of the game. You can easily lose a battle even with an overwhelming force if you make bad choices. It is a much better system than the static system of games like Civ 5 and Warlock: Master of the Arcane. You actually fight battles on a tactical map where positioning and ability use are important.My only real gripe is that diplomacy is a lot less developed than some other 4x games. Hopefully the developers will improve on that in future updates.A solid and fun game overall if you are a fan of 4x games.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												It's a cross between Civilization and a fantasy tactics game (e.g. Final Fantasy Tactics).  It's got all the makings of a classic tactics game.  You'll level up your main hero (or sovereign) and your individual champions, research new spells, complete quests, find new equipment with special abilities, etc.  All the while, you'll be expanding your empire/kingdom a la Civilization style.  If that sounds awesome, that's cause it is!On top of all of that, it has an extensive map/faction editor, and it even lets you design your own "sovereign", which is surprisingly detailed for a game like this.I've actually been sitting on this game since May of 2013, and I can't believe it's taken me this long to play the damn thing.  I'd strongly encourage everyone out there to give this a whirl.  I know the price tag is a bit daunting considering you've probably never heard of the game, but trust me when I say it's worth it.  If not now, wait until one of the holiday sales.  In any event, if you're a fan of Civ games, and fantasy games do yourself a favor and get into this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												If you are a fan of Civiisation V, or any of the series fo CIV, then you will love this game.Take the city screen in Civ... in this game, you see the city straight out.Combat in Civ is quick combat... in this game, you play turn based on a grid... but have the option to do Quick Combat.Both Games have tech trees that are great.However this game shines with what you can do.  Firstly you start out with a hero.  This hero can choose from one of five tech trees, and each tech tree has around 3 paths, with only 1 you will be able to max out, so lots of deferent playthroughs  in the combat if you change your hero.In Civ you can get bored when you are building stuff, but in this world it has NPS, monsters that roam, quests, loot to find, epic monsters.  So you take your hero out to level up.So if I take my hero and 2 mages.  We all get xp if we survive a battle.  The mage can level up and also I can custom creat units which is epic.  With this you can make mages wear plate armour if you fancy it.  It really is epic.The more you do in the world your fame will increase and you'll get other hereos to help you.All in all... A BLAST... I played 24 hours straight, playing as the Necomancer Mage in a Large classic map.  Also dipped into the scenerio which is a story line verson of the game, teachign you about the npc and monsters you will find in classic mode.I'll give this 100% as it is such an iteration of CIV in a fantasy world.  If CIV VI takes this approach it would be great, but otherwise this game has it cooking and it tastes great.  Have FUN!

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Addicting, BEWARE! I didn't like the previous Elemental games, they were alpha to designing this game I belive. Stardock broke away from the space gener and into the gothic fantasy realm, I hope they can continue with designing great games like this for years to come!---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Since this first review and many hours of playing, I have dicided that I can not recomend this game.It is buggy as hell! It wasn't that bad prior to the updates, just a bug here and there, but now it is not possible to even complete a game with out it crashing or just doing weird things. One example that really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off was that while I was being attacked in a city full of Elite units by a full army of the attacker, some of my units would not participate and were not present for the battle, maybe as many as half! And after, they were recorded as defeted, GONE...all my Elite units that were over the battle field unit limit! the cities I guess were not designed big enough to support large battles, so the game just kills them off at start of battle. This is a HUGH bug.Actually the game was fine till the last Heros expansion. It ruined this playable broke game.I had high expectations for this game after pre ordering Elemental, and finding out it wasn't even close to being complete. This game is not complete either it seems.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME IN ITS PRESENT STATE (with the expansions anyway).I will not purchas another Stardock game...EVER.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												It's like Heroes of Might and Magic and Sid Meiers Civ series had a baby. I see some criticism in the reviews but frankly I find them unfounded.Unlike the Civ series, there is always something to do if you feel like it. The game encompasses exploring, RPG, strategy, empire building, tactical combat kin to the Age of Wonders game and much more.One of my favourite parts of the game is that you can design your own hero and in time design your own troop units. As always, as it is with any game, it takes some time to get a feel for how everything works, and usually when I've learned what I need I don't find the game so intruiging anymore. But this game has me going on and on. Do I recommend it? Oh Yeah!If you kinda liked Age of Wonders, Heroes of Might and Magic and Sid Meiers Civ, this game is for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Do you like the Civilization game series? How about Heroes of Might and Magic?  Think of this game as their 'not the sharpest knife in the drawer' child.  Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes tries to be a game of both City-Building and Turn-Based-Combat. Unfortunately it does both of these in wonderful mediocrity.  Neither aspect of the game is fleshed out fully and this leaves you somewhat unsatisfied in both arenas. That being said, the game is not without merit. While it's not as deep as other games, it's a decent way to scratch your TBS itch. The character models are decent and the inclusion of a fantasy setting makes the city-building interesting when starting out. The game isn't worth the asking price of $40, but if you see it on sale for $10 or less, it's probably worth your time if you're a fan of Civilization and TBS games.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Had such potential to be a great Fantasy "Civ" based game, but too many consistent bugs killed it's potential.  From issues with memory leaks to saved games not working correctly as the AI players seem to get super powerful on long games you've played over multiple days of saves, to Dragons walking on to enemy AI armies and not even attacking them, only chase you down, to tamed beasts disappearing when you bring them in to a city *poof*.  The more you play it the more frustrated you get by all the little annoying bugs.  If the bugs were cleaned up, it would be one of my top 10, until then, its going to sit dormant in my steam non-favorite list.  :(

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												The adventuring against monsters, bandits and other NPCs early in this game is a lot of fun, and the character classes and skills are interesting - especially when you add in those you can get in mods.Unfortunately the AI of the AI controlled kingdoms is pretty poor and the AI kingdoms' units mostly look and act pretty much the same as one another, which makes the later part of any game a bit dull.Add to this the lack of any multiplayer andwhat could have been a great game is just an ok one which usually tails off into being dull late in the game.Best mods i've tried are Demons and Wizards - which actually improves the AI a fair bit - and Legacy of Magic, which adds large amounts of technology to research, tonnes of items and NPCs, though the AI is still mostly poor in it. Character Bonanaza adds a lot of new characters too.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												By far, the closest I have ever found to a remake of Masters of Magic (MOM).  It is kind of like Civ 3 or 4, but with heros, items, and turn-based tactical combat instead of a automatic random number generator.  The AI is pretty good for the start of middle of a game, but once you cross a certain power threshold (usually 2x to 3x as powerful as them) you can win just by declaring war and then asking for their surrender.  The only down side, is that when they surrender, you get their main guy as a hero, but the rest of the citys and outposts get destroyed.Overall, great game, but Eador might be a better verson of MOM, but this is the 100% spiritual reincarnation.

												The tutorial can now be played without forcing you to restart the program. This is about the only thing Legendary Heroes does better than the original Fallen Enchantress. The issue of the game not properly closing persists, the AI is if anything even more cheaty (thirty turns in I and most of the AI factions are in scores around the 10s and 20s except for one faction that had a score of 570, and one faction has the ability to instantly capture one city per turn without a fight with no way to avoid it). number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Love this game. Build your own Soveriegn, choose a race, choose the  strengths and weaknesses of your Kingdom/Empire and then take on a world overun by monsters and other factions after a cataclysm. You can use the default unit designs they provide or make your own, name them what you want and rename them on the battlefield. "Atlar Heavy Infantry to Jamie's Besiegers" for example. This game can by as immersive as you want. The aim of this 4x game is to successfully manage your faction towards one of 5 victory conditions whilst fending off the awakened monsters of the world and other soveriegns. If you have played the civilation series you will feel right at home here. Diplomacy suffers alot compared to Civ but this game makes up for it in other ways. Customisable heroes and turn-based battles are examples.Would have liked to see more customisation options to really go to town with your factions own unique identity and it would have been nice to see some more 'Master Quests'

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Lots of cool options and custimization for both hero units and regular units. Factions have slightly different play styles, though it's nothing drastic. You can even create your own factions along with a main character for it.It has a bit of a learning curve, but not too steep. The action tends to slow down after you defeat all the lower level creatures in the area, and have to start venturing towards other players. Diplomacy was simple for me: I liked having clear answers and numerical values during trades instead of having to guess whether your diplomat is skilled enough to overcome the hatred between your nations, as seen in other 4X titles.If you like 4X games as well as RPGs, I strongly recommend this game. Doesn't seem to have a strong story line, but if you can invest in giving your own characters a voice, there's plenty to commit to.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												I really enjoyed this game. It's similar to games like Civilization or Warlocks: Master of the Arcane but the details are all heavily changed to create a very unique entry into the genre. Given how much there are to games like this, I'll just highlight things that stood out to me that I liked and didn't like.What I liked:+Each leader/faction felt significantly different from the other factions -- There's a lot of different units, spells and bonuses that each faction gets to make you get a different experience playing with each one. +The game's combat is really fun -- You can play in a top down view isometric grid type combat or auto-calc. The auto-calc is weird, so sometimes you suffer some bad losses and sometimes you win a battle you could have never won, however I found this feature to be more in my favor than ever against me and I normally only did it in situations where I would obviously win to save time. Additionally you can create very large armies with very powerful units so that a combat victory is much more feasible than in a game like Civilization.+The random stuff on the map is quite fun -- The game has a quest system which, while basic, is actually pretty fun in short bursts. Additionally there is the option to have a ton of monsters and animals to keep yourself busy with them. On top of all that there is a dedicated area on each map where a ludicrously over-powered monster reigns who you can fight for some sweet items.+The hero system is pretty fun -- At first heros seem awesome. Heroes can use spells, equip gear, have special properties that buff your army or a city they occupy. In combat they aren't useful later in game because their stats just don't scale well, but their spells/city/group buffs can be worth it. Each hero is very different so it's something to explore.+The city system is really good and has great progression -- Each city levels up and as they level you can choose a specialization for them, offering bonuses to that particular city. This is really cool and offers you a new level of customization. I found myself regularly creating 1 resource heavy city and then making several combat cities to amass a horde of overpowered soldiers.What I didn't like:-The game isn't technically perfect -- Sometimes you try to click something on the map and the game has it's own mind. Sometimes walking to a particular place is a real pain. These were fairly minimal interruptions, but over the course of 50 hours it was enough to make me complain about it. Also as mentioned earlier the auto-calcuation battles can be wonky. Sometimes I would start a fight manually, then once I realized I couldn't win, I'd auto-calc to end my suffering. However, I'd end up winning a fair amount of those battles somehow. It didn't bother me because it was a nice surprise, but it may be a break in realism for others.-There is a steep learning curve -- The game has a lot of stuff to it, much like civ. The difference is that in this game the combat is more present, so you do need to be more up to snuff. I found myself being demolished in about 3 (...practice) games before I could finally conquer others, even on easier settings. The monsters can be a real threat, which is nice later on, but at the start it can be overwhelming.If you like any sort of strategy, please try this game. I was sad I was so hesistant in buying it (I didn't buy it until it hit $10, easily worth $40). Please note this review is based on the game without any of the DLC.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												This game is obscure, even for a 4X. We all know our Civilizations or Dominions or Alpha Centauris, but I barely know anyone who's heard of this, let alone played it. That being said, this game could be described a rough diamond. The game has some glaring balance issues, and it's a good bit glitchy at times, but the gameplay is solid and rewarding.Every game begins like any Civilization game, where you found your capital city and then start to explore the world. However, instead of your standard units like Civilization has, you have customized units that you can design yourself. You also have heroes, which are specialty one-man armies that will join your cause from time to time. If you've played Age of Wonders III, the combat is remarkably similar. When you enter battle, both factions are placed on the opposite side of the battlefield, and you move them into play until they're in range to strike. The world itself is incredibly detailed. On almost every playthrough, I'll run into a quest or monster that I've never seen before, and every game spawns one of four special areas of the map where you can fight boss-type monsters and aquire extremely rare treasure. Every game brings something new.PROS:- Incredibly varied worlds- Good combat system- Lots of "fluff" - Wide variety of artifacts and weapons- Useful character creatorCONS:- Some factions just plain suck- Game can be glitchy, particularly when loading saves- Soundtrack's rather forgettable FINAL VERDICTFirst off, buying this game with all the DLC will leave you homeless. When our Lord and Savior Gaben blesses this software with the glorious green of a sale, snatch it up as soon as you can. You won't be disappointed.
