It's turn based, so you can walk away at any time.The level of detail present in the world is unlike any other game of this type, barring perhaps Galactic Civilizations, also by Stardock. The world of Elemental comes to life as you zoom into your town, deploy on the battlefield, hunt relics, or zoom out to the cloth map (they did it first). I highly recommend this title.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Tried the demo. A hybrid between Heroes of Might and Magic and Civilizations.PROS1. Story looks interestingBut I couldn't grasp anything interesting from the introductory video beyond "you must tame the land". So, I got pretty bored but I'm sure there is a lot of backstory.2. A lot of stuffA lot of tech which happens to resemble the Civilization tech tree for easy recognition. CONS1. Same problems as HOMMYou're going to have problems with scaling up. Automating battles may cause your units to suffer damage which you try to avoid, thus causing you to play every tactical battle to min-max and prevent troop loss.2. Actions that could be passivesHave to be next to your town to cast "Inspiration" (adds 1 research) for 0 mana is something that should be a passive. Getting additional techpoints are quite important in 4X games e.g. helping to wonder rush. It would be quite ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to have a hero stand around to cast some sort of "bless thine city" spell.If you want to have to make a choice of which spell to cast, force a choice between 2 passives.3. Redundant spellsYou have to play a tactical battle with a spellcaster that begins with up to 9 spells and only 1 move, 1 action per turn. A lot of pretty redundant spells. Lots of choice but not able to execute everything. Spells/abilities cooldown in about 5 turns, so unless you want to play an ultra draggy battle that will be a game by itself, I would not suggest this. I do not see the fun of dragging out "click and attack" battles.4. Tactical combat - Direction of AttackCan't see which direction I'm going to attack my enemy from.There might be direction arrows in the game but I couldn't easily find them.5. Tactical combat - EndingThe battles end like HOMM, one winner one loser, which is a problem. There is no tactical retreat or running away. Auto-resolve just ends with one side dead. No kiting, hit-and-run or guerilla tactics, just a ringed match.6. Tactical Comabt - No of turnsDrags the game on for a longer period of time. In the strategic map, only 1 season (day) would have passed.7. Extreme similarity to CivSettler is a pioneer, Scout is a Scout, Library is a Library, etc, etc.I was hoping for uniqueness from Fallen Enchantress, not a portover from Civilization.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												The game degrades memorywise the longer you play. So first it gets slower, then the waterlevel disappears, then wrong colors and missing parts happen all over the game. If this isn´t already annoying, the most encountered bug in the game (trying to go to the main menue and reloading a gamesave makes the game crash entirely) completes it. The game is like a kid, that tries to ram too much sweets(data) down his throat and almost suffocates trying it. If they would fix this single problem and you ignore the other bugs, the game could go as a computergame. But for now it is what it is...unstable. Now just my taste:Comparing Fallen Enchantres with Master of Magic is a little bit bold. MoM had better suited spells in the line from weak to powerful, even many of them not the usual fireball stuff we have in this game. And I used most of them in the game, not like here, where I only use few and the rest never or rare. Plus the computer ai loves to use inferior spells more in combat like useful spells: for example giant grow instead of healing an almost dead unit (seen often enough). MoM had buildings, that brought new features, not new (and always same) boni. MoM had units and creatures, that aren´t effect catchers with the appearance of Sauron and oversized, absolutly stupid designed weapons. And erm....MoM had alot less platitudes in it´s game texts. I always roll my eyes, when I have to read the subtexts of most characters.... :) It is like a 6 year old trying to produce somekind of epic zitate.

												first impression, based on free trial.++ this game is very curstmizable.   + you have multiple factions and multiple magic schools   + you can select traits for both your faction and your leader.   + you can reqruit heroes and level them as you wish.   + you can equip your leader your heroes and your basic units as you wish.   + you can paint anything as you wish.this is all great! and i would love this in almost any other game! however the game is just no fun...combat is weird... with unit turns based on their initiative... which sound logical, and some board games have similar mechanics... but it doesnt feel right...while you can customize all of your units, and the individual assets are pretty decent... the game somehow still looks very dated and ugly... which is weird...the map is square grid based, and does not look fun... the quests structures and everything else are just randomly splattered around... and it just doesnt look/feel good....  civ V random maps are beautiful and feel natural... these don't...this game has so many cool mechanics... and most of them are implemented pretty well... yet somehow it just doesnt work :(

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												I've never heard of this game before but I saw it at a 'free weekend' and, remembering my fond feelings for turn-based strategies, decided to give it a try. Well, after playing through the night and finishing one random game, one thing is for sure: I'm not going to buy it after the time runs out.This game is tedious. I started with the tutorial and, boy, were the introductory videos long and unnecessary! I got to the end of only one of them, skipping all the others, and didn't feel like I was missing something. Then there was the main game. For me it went like this: settle down, start expanding - ooh, it's getting interesting - die trying to explore, meet neighboors, avoid their units and wandering monsters while trying to explore and expand, upgrade your cities and lose your units on the way to join main guy's army - repeat for many turns until you know the map - start negotiating, get into a war, sign a peace treaty - rinse and repeat, that's where I lost the last of my interest for this game, during those many turns where nothing happened - finally be strong enough to follow the main storyline and immediately after wait again for who knows how long for new units to be trained in place of the fallen ones. Yeah, boring.I got three endings: the ultimate spell (which I did only out of curiosity, not knowing that it will end the game), by losing to the final dragon behind the gates and by killing it (last two with the use of cheats because of the difficulty jump - I could easily kill any monster or AI unit on the map but this thing obliterates me in, like, three turns? Yeah, no, I'm not grinding for that - and by the way: those cheats? Did not help much). I didn't try to conquer all the other nations just because I couldn't be bothered anymore and wanted to be done with it. And my rating was always 4/10 (I think) despite having, like, twenty fully upgraded cities and finishing all reasearch and quests.Also, this game doesn't have window mode which incredibly bothered me and the loading process took way longer than it should. Maybe my machine isn't powerful enough, although I thought it didn't have to be to play a top-down strategy game! On the technical side of the things, thank god there is an auto-battle option, cause I don't think I would have gotten this far without it! Never played a battle on my own (except the final dragon one but that one doesn't count) and immensely grateful for that.TL;DRActually, this game is not so bad - for the first few hours. After that, if you're not a fan of the wainting game, it becomes too much. Maybe it's supposed to be played in short sessions, who knows, but for me one run was more than enough.Never would've thought of buying this game before; certain that I'd not now.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												When I first purchased Elemental way back years ago, I had every hope it would make for a great table top RPG platform as well as the regular strategy game it was designed to be. When I got my copy I was able to see what could be, but it was still an “alpha” game… So I let it go,  kept checking the progress and changes overtime, but nothing got my attention. Then along came 1.7 update and much of what I read I liked so I purchase Legendary Heroes. A BIG WOW!I am so happy the developers never gave up. This is very much what they had promised back when they were making the first Elemental. There is still room for improvement (lots of potential for growth and expansion), but the main concept is all there! So, soon as  they let us make scenarios using the “workshop”,  a custom monster toolset (like the spell toolset) and add a hot seat feature to the game it will appeal to many D&D table top players like myself.  I love the way the mechanics and AI  have developed and evolved/improved, I love the customization aspect so, so, so, very much. Changing gear is actually visible in game play, love the way cities can level as well as almost everything else, we just need equipment to level as well (hopes). The artwork is splendid. I have loved the art from day one! So perfect for this kind of game, the way the story is presented through text and that unique artwork makes me feel like I am actually reading a D&D campaign and I can get my fiends involved (rolling dice to make decisions, character customization, etc.) we played all night as if we were playing table top, and we never once looked at the time, it was great fun, different, but not so different that it did not work. It is thanks to the freedom to customize just about everything that makes this game so rewarding and usable as a tool for a good old fashion table top game. If you have an imagination and fun friends to play with give this a try. ( mind you we are doing this without hot seat or multiplayer, image if we had that!)In short I am very happy that my bias for DLC’s went away almost instantly, “sell me as many DLC's for this game as you want!" if they are useful and enhances the game like the current DLC’s.  If you love fantasy strategy games give this version of the game a try, you will love it more and more every turn you take, there is something different and new for your imagination to create in good fun! Recommend!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												I haven't reviewed many games, but I've logged more hours into this game than any other in my library so far, including Skyrim. It's a very detailed strategy game that includes Civilization style kingdom/empire building from a starting date (after a world-shattering cataclysm) until you achieve one of multiple possible victories over the competition. Similarities to Civilization include focusing research to unlock new city improvements, resources, units, and abilities; expanding your country through exploration or conquest; making trade agreements, treaties, and war with other factions; and turn-based actions for all levels of the game. However, this game also includes a lot of plot. There are some default scenarios you can play to see what the underlying relationship is between each of the sovereigns. Even if you choose to just do a custom map or pre-set map without a scenario, you are able to control a soverign character and heroes s/he recruits to complete quests, explore the map, and level up customized ability trees. This comes into play into the larger faction planning because leveling these characters unlocks abilities and bonuses that can boost any other aspect of the game and can lead to extremely powerful units that can trounce through ordinary enemies. There's not as many factions as similar games, but the bonuses are fairly unique to each sovereign and allow for enough variation that trying different game types is a good way to learn new strategies. The fantasy theme is also very fun. There was a lot of effort and creative writing with the incredible number of quests and lore that is inlcuded in each game. The DLC adds even more. Overall, I just haven't gotten bored with this game. It's a lot of fun and worth the full price, though I did find it on sale when I purchased it. That said, if I had played a demo beforehand, I would have gladly paid the full price if no sale was offered. I had no qualms about paying for DLC, each of the ones I have so far were worth it.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												A decent 4X game with a decent fantasy universe. many, many possibilities. 10 races with special traits, 6 carriers for your heros, 5 kind of magic, 3 trees of research, many weapons and armor (or dodge) and various equipements, cities, outposts, and even cosmetic option for your heros. etc. I could score it 4 stars out of 5. So why "no" ?Trouble is : this is too much. Too much for the AI, that cannot cope. So it's very poor. Too much for the player, who just has to cut through this mess by keeping simple. Bottom line : this game offer a wealth of possibilities, except that the whole point of the game seems to teach the player to NOT use them. What a pity ... Many troups are available ? don't care. Don't bother to research bows, cavalery or armor or mages : the couple of spears that you'll have to spawn in the beginning of the game will make the party that will carry you to victory, thanks to experience and improvements, with the help of a pair of monsters (rewards for questing), 1 or 2 heros that will come with your fame, and a catapult when available. Same for your heroes. Don't bother to ask yourself if they should use bow, axe, sword or mace, 1H or 2H : just make use of whatever comes as loot. add any kind of magic and that's it. Oh, and forget assassin, warriors defenders or whatever. You need mages and admnistratorsSame for your cities. Just build one or two with max food, add outposts, and that's it. Same for diplomacy. Same for gameplay. Just bother to quest and kill roaming monsters for loot and XP, so as to build a party that will cut throught anythingetc.

												OK - so I loaded up Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes... Now it wants me to make an additional account. So I am goign to leave it afk on thier request page and earn its cards without ever even looking at the game. I like steam becuase I don't have to deal with uneeded registrations and spamming my e-mail acount to bussinesses' automated advertisement bots. Enjoy Stardock!**Edit**-_-|I couldnt stop myself...... They got me to sign up with their luancher. Nuuu!!!!Resulting game play gave me the following thoughts:For a game with so much to offer, they missed what I feel are the basics.Game play is generic.Focus seems to be on the heros that you can gain and how you level them. The fighting is boring with a predictable AI and terrain that has no advantage in battle. I was so underwelmed from the fighting that I ended up hitting the automated attack button. The most action I got out of this game was hitting the End Turn button to speed up building.No city design controll.Perhaps this next issue won't bother you, but it irritated me to no end. You cannot place the items in your town were you would liek them to go. You just hit the develop button and then order the items you want made first.UI is unfriendlyThis section is to complain about how unfriendly the controll are in this game. Although mastery of the UI is not hard, it does not feel natural. A few more easy to use button would have made a large differnce as well as a few windows. For instance, I would have like a better way to form war parties instead of clicking on the town, then the soldier, then a blank square outside the city, and then finally repeat for each other soldier I want in the group making sure to have them join the same square outside of town. Even if it only took a couple of minutes, that is time further waisted through uneeded tedium.My final adivceThere are better browser 4x games for free out there. I would pass on this game unless you are looking at a massive discount.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes aspires to be a great game, and all the elements of a good turn based fantasy strategy game are there, unfortunetly, after 40+ hours of playing it, i have to say, while it is addicting, it is not very fun to play it.I am sure there are people who have lots of fun playing at the start like an ant wich has to be careful where to build it howel least the many wandering beings of power trample it. Scurry around with you units like rats in a field full of cats and larger predators, and pray that none of the monsters, who are at this point unbeatable, notice you.I know what others playing the game will say, that nothing is unbeatable given time. Well sure, but time is not something you have for it when there are AI rivals on the world, who are absolutly unnaffected by the same creatures building their empires, (And don't you dare claim othervise, i have seen unescorted pioneers of the AI walk around dragons and wandering ogre armies unmolested. And no, they did not have the stealthy trait.) this is frustrating at the least.That is not to say it cannot be an enjoyable game, and that you could not beat it. (Sometimes easily, even on harder difficulties.) But luck is too much of a factor, and it is infuriating to realise that you are screwed after an hour of playing, because a creature with physical immunity wandered into your territory (And you have no magic yet), or a random event spawned a swarm of giant spiders on top of your capital that is stronger as your entire armed forces.In a faster game these issues could be looked over, but Fallen Enchantress is Slooowww. I love empire building, i have no problems with a game being slow, but when it is slow, and a bit of bad luck can be game ending, and you have to restart over and over again to get a starting position that is not full of nasties you cannot beat until after midgame tech, that is simply bad design.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I am a fan of strategic RPGs. So I might have had high expectations towards FE. There are several aspects worth mentioning.1. Movement: most units have a movement range of two squares. None can pass mountains or oceans/lakes. There are no teleporter. But in later game you can learn a spell to transport your troops to any location you desire. This makes the game extremely lengthy and IMHO dull. Having learnd the spell of transportation it is giving too much of an advantage.2. Tactical combat: your maximum number of attackers is nine units (i.e. a group of soldiers) or champions. When you attack a city, any defending unit or champion will be supported by a number of city units, depending on the buildings errected in this city. There are no obsticals like city walls to hinder the attackers. This makes every battle follow the same pattern: try to kill the archers as quick as possible and mob up the rest. Even if you bring more troops you cannot stack them. My city was once attacked by four groups one after the other in the same round and for every city unit that was killed a new city unit (level 1 though) stepped forward. After a while that is boring.3. Diplomatic system: normally every fraction is going to negotiate with you. And normally you can persuade every fraction to do what you want regardless of their opinion towards you. It will just cost you more. You can trade knowledge and resources but no citys or resoureces pits. Your opponents switch their alliance at random. Or so it seems to me. What is the use of a long-time friend to turn on you whilest every other fraction already is at war with him? That has to be done better.4. Game stability: crap. I dont have to go into this deeper. Just read some of the other comments.5. Research: there are just very few research differences for the different races.6. Injury system: whenever your monarch or one of his/her champions is beaten they will not die. They start over in the nearest city with all their equipment. All the receive as a punishment is a recreation period during which they cannot move and to a champion a random injury. That injury gives the champion a malady: for example less hit points or less strengh. Such injuries will stay with the champion until they are lifted by a potion which can be produced as a consequence of a city achivement. Even a level-up will not effect the injury. So when my champions were defeated several times, they literally became cripples. Moreover, there is a potion to lift all injuries of a person at once but you cannot produce it in your cities. So you have to buy the healing potion several times for 400 gp each.Conclusion: FE: Legendary Heroes is way behind other products of the genre. Even the older Age of Wonders 2 (which I still do recommend as ground-breaking) is better and more stable.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												So I picked up this game for the free weekend, having never actually played a build civilization stratagy game before. A stand-a-lone game by Stardock, upon the opening intro I see interesting artwork and fantasy. The story line or plot is pretty basic. You choose between 10 soverign or heros, who aim to rule/conquer the world of Elemental. Witch has been torn asunder and is in ruins ripe to be brought together again by cataclysm. The soverigns themselves and their civilizations are very themed and have a style of their own. A unique gameplay for whoever you choose. I selected Magnar. I was drawn to (naturally) by his warlock abilities and the story line of ( I'm a dragon/human thing called a Quendar, Were old and ancient and you're not. So I shall make slaves and use fire and death magic to rule the weak. ) Cool huh? A short tuturial and you can jump into the game.  Using you'r soverign you build and take over the world of Elemental. Build settlements and watchposts to increase your economy and research warfare/civilization/magic. It took a while to get the hang of all the micro-managing but after a while I think I got the hang of it. More heros DO join your civilization, while it grows in fame and fortune. Witch they want a part of , butt chose wisely your heros to your strengths and game play. Also you have to build an army or two to kill wild animals, bandits, undead, demons, trolls, ogres and everything else you can think of in the fantasy world. I was rather impressed by the monster library in the game. During all this you can also pick up quests to complete mainly by killing or collecting things while your doing your build civilization thang. And then you have the other soverigns to deal with ! Oh yeah and there is these huge epic elemental boss guys that'll pop up that'll try to destroy you....This game was interestingly addicting by the fact of I MUST BUILD MY EMPIRE BIGGER.  and level up my soverin and heros to rule the weak. An almost primal urge of destroy and conquer kinda takes over. A lot of content to get lost in while you play It's defineitly a game to pick up if you have a chance.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												I immediately bought this when I found out about it because I adore the old Heroes of Might and Magic games and the Age of Wonders franchise, and I really wanted something newer and better to play with my friends.Those of you who know this game already know what my first problem is... No multiplayer?! I assumed it had multiplayer since every similar game that went before it has multiplayer, but boy was I stupid not to have checked that little detail beforehand. And there won't be any multiplayer in the future either.Oh well, I like to play those games in single player mode too, so all's not lost... And the gameplay is great. It's better than HoMM and AoW. It really is a step forward, and not only graphically.But that positive note was dashed almost immediately. This game is buggier than an ant-farm (on windows XP certainly, on windows 7 less so). It used to crash right before it saved (only a game that corrupts its own savegames is more annoying), but still I had to save often because a slew of other things could go wrong, so many actions could lead to crippling or annoying bugs that it isn't possible to sum them up here. After a few updates the saving issue was gone but other bugs popped up. To this day the bugs make this game practically unplayable, and that is a crying shame, because it really is a good game at heart.7/10 if they get the bugs out. 3/10 as it is right now.

												Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes is an extremely fun and addictive 4X game in a beautiful setting. Customization is amazing, I always play my own faction and own hero. content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This is a great game in the making. If you like early access games this might be for you.The problem is, this isn't an early access game. This is the predecessor of this game, with minor patches. The changes and added content in this "stand alone expansion" are an order of magnitude less than what I've ever seen in any expansion, stand alone or otherwise. And the game itself is only 75% done - it is still unfinished, unbalanced, and riddled with more bugs than any finished game should have in the late Beta phase. The things that are unfinished are:- A ridiculous amount of bugs (e.g. wrong camera perspective in worldmap until you restart, missing tooltips that should tell you how strong the enemy is, cannot select a unit until you restart, music stops until you restart, game crashes, etc), usually I encounter about 2 of these per hour.- Performance (runs very slow on Haswell integrated graphics)- AI is very very weak- Lategame gameplay not interesting, due to bad balance and AI- Manual and in-game help incomplete, not usableA few balance changes and A LOT of bugfixes, and this game would be good. Add in a decent AI and it would be great. Unfortunately it doesn't have these and never will, so thumbs down.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												This game had some good elements, but I would say that most aspects of it fall short. Its like civilization and your units group in an army and you go to a battle screen kind of like Total War games. Except the battles are turn based and I have a lot of problems with the battles, The ranged units can hit anywhere on the map... So your weaker mages or archers get picked off easy, especially if you auto-resolve, all your weak units will be dead, all other units no damage. Also the fights start pretty much face to face, first person to move usually gets the kill. One thing that really annoyed me was the character models, they are going for a RPG element with lots of items for heros, except the heros and items look sooo horribly bad, Like I dont understand how these days, even a modest graphic designer could probably nock out some really good character and item models. The game might be worth getting for under 5 bucks, other than that pass it up. If you really want a city building fantasy battle game go for Warlock - Master of the Archane, seems like a nice one so far,

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Hi, I've just played this game during the trial weekend. As other people have said, this is Civilization meets HoMM, both of which are series that I have enjoyed very much. There is also a resemblance to Age of Wonders. Many of the elements of this game are very well done.Pros:+Turn Based Combat System is well executed in general+Graphics are decent for Turn-Based 4x games+Customisable Characters+Interesting weapon array+Interesting skills available+Quest system is really coolCons:-Game is a bit too complex (for me), as an RPG is good, as a 4x is good, but both is a bit confusing and hard to manage-Hard to understand city system and resources (not clear enough what buildings actually do and how the city evolves)-Too easy to build pioneers, cities should be hard to build!!In conclusion, I feel this game would appeal to fans of civilization who like to play the game on normal or slow settings and fans of total war. This game requires a lot of effort to understand the mechanics but it *might be* worth it. For me though, I didn't feel it was replayable enough as every game seemed to feel the same (I just wanted things to hurry up!), and perhaps I missed out on important aspects of the game. I'm giving it a 'Yes' recommendation as there is no 'Maybe' button and it was nice to give a trial weekend.Recommend? Maybe.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes aspires to be a great game, and all the elements of a good turn based fantasy strategy game are there, unfortunetly, after 40+ hours of playing it, i have to say, while it is addicting, it is not very fun to play it.I am sure there are people who have lots of fun playing at the start like an ant wich has to be careful where to build it howel least the many wandering beings of power trample it. Scurry around with you units like rats in a field full of cats and larger predators, and pray that none of the monsters, who are at this point unbeatable, notice you.I know what others playing the game will say, that nothing is unbeatable given time. Well sure, but time is not something you have for it when there are AI rivals on the world, who are absolutly unnaffected by the same creatures building their empires, (And don't you dare claim othervise, i have seen unescorted pioneers of the AI walk around dragons and wandering ogre armies unmolested. And no, they did not have the stealthy trait.) this is frustrating at the least.That is not to say it cannot be an enjoyable game, and that you could not beat it. (Sometimes easily, even on harder difficulties.) But luck is too much of a factor, and it is infuriating to realise that you are screwed after an hour of playing, because a creature with physical immunity wandered into your territory (And you have no magic yet), or a random event spawned a swarm of giant spiders on top of your capital that is stronger as your entire armed forces.In a faster game these issues could be looked over, but Fallen Enchantress is Slooowww. I love empire building, i have no problems with a game being slow, but when it is slow, and a bit of bad luck can be game ending, and you have to restart over and over again to get a starting position that is not full of nasties you cannot beat until after midgame tech, that is simply bad design.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2013
												I was a silent "victim" of the War of Magic debacle; I preordered the game a year before the first beta was released.  Fallen Enchantress and especially Legendary Heroes more than made up for that mess.  I would never say that this is the next Master of Magic, as it is a competely different game.  Much of what makes the game great is due to the company's engagement with its customers; the feedback given over the last few years has shaped everything from the interface to the math going on behind the scenes.  If turn based fantasy is something you like, you can not miss this, and honestly, there isn't much else in that genre to play right now...

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												I spent money for it so I'd hope to be able to recommend it. Alas, not to be.It's not a bad game, really. It's just that, in 79 hours, I've figured out how to utilize the tech tree and can advance faster than the Hard AI can. Having done that, I just take what I want and no one ever tries to stop me.Some of the Rulers are pretty weak, so, one could handicap themselves by playing those, I suppose. Here are what I see as problems.1. Everyone will tell you that the random mobs are often vastly superior to what you can field, especially early on. That these advanced mobs attack your armies AND your cities, long before you can cope with them, is very frustrating. It's the cause of a lot of re-starts.2. It takes long periods of time to recruit army units. Thus, it's long into the game before you can mount any credible force UNLESS you simply allow your research and tech improvements to just languish and build weak units. The AI will happily flood the land with pioneers that take control of the valuable areas while you fall behind while building troops. But, he won't bother to defend them! He'll allow you to take his outposts and the resources there with no opposition. Instead, he waits until they're again undefended to send in some throwaway units to re-take them...maybe.3. Happily, you can leave your cities pretty much unguarded against the AI opponents. They NEVER attack you. They'll build outposts and garner resources and, left entirely alone, create 4-5 units in their cities. But, they never put together any large forces to attack, just a few units that putz around doing nothing aggressive to you. The AI sends in lone heroes to battle vastly tougher mob armies and, of course, lose. The heroes usually don't die, just return to a city, maimed, to recuperate. Maybe that's the AI's method of getting them experience? It's fruitless, though.4. There's Epic (that's YOUR army) and then there's EPIC (that's the AI mobs). Taking YOUR epic army to battle and watching a dragon eat 4-5 entire units in one turn let's you know that you can't trust the game's evaluations. Weak and medium, well, they're not too badly graded. Once you get to strong, deadly, and epic, it's prety iffy as to your relative strength.5. Why does the AI declare war and then just sit in his cities, waiting for you to take them? Why does the AI declare war at all? I know they fight each other and take cities. I think they're just as handicapped as the player when it comes to fielding armies.So, I won't be buying any DLCs for this game and I don't advise anyone to spend money on this game.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes is an odd game to me. Personally, I don't like turn-based games because I don't have the patience to wait for my next turn. But, somehow, I still bought this game because I like the RPG-element in it. Against my expectations I really liked the game because the world looks pretty awesome with the magic and monsters (especially the dragons.. I love dragons). I have spent a lot of time creating new factions and sovereigns because you want to try everything out when you see something new. NOTE: Sovereigns and heroes are not the same thing in this game.The point of the game is to build a kingdom/empire, research and defeat or work together with the enemy AI's, kill monsters (there are dragons, giant spiders and some really epic monsters I  haven't encountered yet) and there can be an event going on like the plague, the shroud (can't remember what it was). All in all, you must make a lot of choices; Shall I attack these monsters and leave my base undefended or shall I make a new squad to defend my base while I'm attacking the enemy? Shall I research better armor or do I need to research better economics? Doing quests around the map gives you items (sometimes unique ones) which your sovereign or hero can equip. Doing quests also increases your fame, fame will get you heroes, heroes will make your army stronger.I had a bit of problem getting the hang of this game. The tutorial wasn't really helpful which is a shame. By restarting the game a few times you will learn the game step by step. So don't expect to get the hang of it right away.Pros:+ Lots of choices between factions and heroes.+ Nice graphics (world, kingdoms/empires) when zoomed out.+ Lots of enemies.+ Challenging.+ Customizing your own faction and Sovereign.Cons:- Most of the battles you will be selecting auto-result (skip the fighting stuff and know the result right away) - Bad graphics (npc's and some monsters) when zoomed in.- Hard to get the hang of this game (I suggest watching some youtube video's first).- When heroes fall they will have permanently decreased stats.- Unpredictable AI. Sometimes out of nowhere they start a war or are angry.  If I had to give this game a score I would give it a 7.5.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Well, I played this for a grand total of 43 minutes, since it's on free demo on Steam at time of writing. I realise this isn't a full review, 43 minutes isn't very long, but the point of a demo is to entice you to want to play the game further, so I can say the demo failed for me.Having never played a Fallen Enchantress game before, I found the controls not very intuitive, and felt frustrated a lot of the time. I don't know if there are ways to choose which things you research in what order, clicking on them didn't do squat, so my research carried on automatically. I couldn't easily see when things I was building would finish, or view or edit my building queue. It took quite a while to work out how to combine units into an army, and the relative limitations of army sizes.Combat is a huge mess. I'm used to being able to wait and move my unit turn further down in the queue, like Heroes of Might & Magic, but instead in this I guess if my unit can't reach the enemy and isn't a long range unit he just has to pass a turn he could still have done *something* in, just not move. Most of my combat turns involved me passing turns, everyone was out of mana pretty much immediately and I wasn't presented with any information on how or when they regained it. I then ran into a battle in which I had to fight a ghost. The ghost is immune to all physical damage. No one has any mana.That was when the 43 minutes elapsed and I decided I'd had enough.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Just not a very good game all around.  First, the graphics are just awful, it feels like the game was developed 10 years ago.  Iif you're going to choose to make a fantasy game, you'd better make sure the graphics are up to par.  You can get away with vector-like graphics and single-digit landscape palettes in a Sci-Fi game like GalCiv, but Stardock shows that when it's applied to fantasy, it just doesn't work.  The story and what little art style there is lacks creativity and is pretty uninteresting.

I hate to say that, but it's the truth.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												My experience with this game is as follows:1)  Unable to actually demo the game on first day (see well known issue with Steam offer re Jan 2015 promo).  Tried many times to launch the game but alas, it wouldn't ....but I wasn't put off.2)  Tried to load game again on second day.  Apparently, I have to give my E-Mail address to an unproven/untrusted  entity, despite nothing having been demonstrated....but I wasn't put off. 3)  Signed up reluctantly.  Game loaded very slowly and laucnhed into a poor, somewhat incoherent, pale immitation to the intro to Lord of The Rings.....but I wasn't put off.4)   Changed AA setting and was told game would have to restart.  Started to get put off.5)  Restarted game.  Took ages to start up.....again.  Getting more put off now.6)  Chose to execute Tutorial.  Tutorial turned out to be more like a 90s infomercial, crammed into a tiny little box about half the size of my screen (?).  Now I'm beginning to get irritated.7)  Attempted to move my character as directed in the tutorial.  Spent 10 minutes trying to move character.  Failed.  Extremely annoyed by now.  8)  Figured #6 must be a bug so exited and restarted game.  Waited again.  Game crashed.  Deleted.  Never again.  Absolutely appaling and pathetic.  1 Hour of my life I'll never get back and an unwarranted invasion of privacy.

												A bit clunky, has some weird bugs (need to restart the game when you reload a save if you want to see any map borders), but a charming game nonetheless. Takes awhile to get used to if you come from Civ games ( city stats depend only on the square you place the city on, if the first square wasn't next to river then you can't build a harbor even after expanding the city to a river... )After getting access to right spells you can redesign the landscape which is awesome.Army and hero management is alright.Battles against an enemy that spams fear suck but oh well.Definitely worth picking up during a sale if you like turn-based 4X + fantasy setting.

												Fallen Enchantress is an awesome mix of Civilization, Spellforce, and King's Bounty. All of these are games I love to pieces. Fallen Enchantress uses the hero and quest system from Spellforce, the Hero leveling and battle system from King's Bounty (with squares instead of hex spaces) and the format of Civilization, with a fantasy twist. Get ready to lose hours of your life playing it!

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Are you ready for a strategic RPG with tactical combat and a vast world to explore?Well too bad! First you need to build your first city, then set research, then maybe you can wait a few turns to build a scout, then maybe find something interesting outside of a two tile radius of where you started the game, and a few turns later, maybe finish researching sticks with pointy ends so you can make spearmen.Or in other words, in spite of how this game tries to sell itself, this game is basically just Civilization with a new coat of paint and a spellbook mechanic.  (Notably, spellbooks are also tied to tech trees, so you get even more "sit and watch a progress bar fill up" fun.) One would think that after over two decades, the formula for these games would be getting refined - even Civilization itself has, for the past decade, done much to try to lessen the micromanagement - but this game and the other low-budget Civ clones prove that some people are just averse to new ideas. In essence, the point of this game is to build cities, expand cities, kill barbarians - I mean monsters - and finally get a conquest/diplomacy/research/whatever ending.  There's also a unit customization screen, although that made a whole lot more sense in Galactic Civilizations than here, and the low polys on the characters and fact that selecting a cloak makes your character go bald make it both a bit frustrating and unsatisfying as a means of customizing your troops.  At best, you can make one class of soldier have a red hat instead of a green one to tell them apart more easily.  I can't recommend this game, as anyone who would want to play a 4X like this might as well play the much better-polished Civ V.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												This game had a hell of a life.  It started out as "Elemental: War of Magic."  However the game had terrible reviews and angry players, so the game was essentially scrapped, recalled and removed from the market.  According to the developer, it shouldn't be availible anywhere. This brings us to Fallen Enchantress.Fallen Enchantress was created to replace War of Magic.  It removed some of the popular features of WoM such as Dynasties. However it added much more.  This was released in place of WoM, and given to free to the origional purchasers of WoM. This game had its life cycle.Then came Legendary Heroes:  Many are confused. This game is mis-advertised as an Expansion, however its really the Successor to FE in the way that FE succeeded WoM.  This doesn't "Expand" anything if you buy FE.  This IS the game in its current line of succession. It isn't WoM, or FE.  It is LH now.This game falls short of the rest of the genre by far. Elemental is better than Eador, and worse than AoW3.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Bad Master of Magic clone...I have picked up the game as part of a free trial weekend as I have not played a 4x fantasy game in some time. Unfortunately it is not what I expected. City improvements for example only give tiny bonuses each, it takes forever to grow a city into something meaningful. You cannot really put a focus or make strategic decisions as each building has almost no affect.The combat is flawed, magic is almost useless. It takes forever to get new mana in the beginning and building new units is a pain. Later on combat is way to simple as you simply pile up units in an army - unbeatable for the AI.To sum this up the game is simply not fun. Playing on a high resolution device (surface 3) also shows that the game has technical problems as you cannot reduce the resolution and still play fullscreen! There is simply no option for fullscdreen in the game menu... and this in 2015. The fact that you need to create an additional stardock account on top of steam is also noteworthy.If you get the game for free try it, maybe get it at a discount. But think really hard before paying full price for that game!I would rate it maybe 4 out of 10.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												A clunky, ugly, Civilization-style 4X strategy game that is overly complicated and makes little effort to explain itself. Fallen Enchantress makes a big deal about its RPG elements, even including a win condition where you can practically play it as a single player RPG to defeat the ancient evil while virtually ignoring your in-game neighbors. You can also equip your (legendary) heroes with armor, weapons, and trinkets, put points into large active & passive skill trees, and use them to enhance your cities, increase your resources, or just go out and kill big monsters. However I feel all this added complexity takes away from the strategy elements of the game and are poorly explained; there is only ONE 10 minute tutorial for the whole game, with everything else explained through tooltips, brief popups and an in-game encyclopedia. In fact, many of the new game "tutorial" popups just link to the in-game manual's page on that topic. If you can look past the low quality, repetitive music, terrible graphics with flat, undetailed textures and poor character models (why is everything so ugly when there are so many close-ups of your heroes?), clunky UI, and tinny SFX, you might have fun with this game. Fallen Enchantress is a very mundane 4X Civilization style strategy game that tries to be something bigger but is too underdeveloped to be worth playing.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												This is an excellent game for anyone with a passing interest in turn based strategy games. I honestly do believe this is the spiritual successor to Age of Wonders or the closest we shall get to it, which is something I've always dreamed would happen.At first I pirated the game and on the second day after I went and purchased it off Steam to support the developers in what way I can, I was that impressed. It has so many layers from the research, the rpg-style exploration and questing to the empire building and warfare. Stardock has really impressed me with how much support they have gone and given this game, it is a light and day difference in terms of quality from the original Elemental to Legendary Heroes and this tells me they really do care about their product and their support for such a great game will not be ending anytime soon. I'll end by saying that the "one more turn" feeling we all love and crave has been captured very well so far for me with Legendary Heroes and what more can you ask for with a game like this? Turn based strategy fans shouldn't even hesitate on giving this game a try and spreading the word. I've been greatly impressed with the amount of work and detail put into this game. Cheers!

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Got it from a giveaway, thank you kind stranger! :)On to the review:-Game itself is very interesting. For starters, you can customize your character so that you can choose what type you want it to be or you can just play with the pre-selected ones. As for the mechanics, its quite hectic. You face other sovereigns in the map and its practically 'the faster, the better'. You need to outpace your enemies in building your city, training your units, and collecting resources for enchantments. This game requires a lot of time, and if you are quite busy, then this could mean that you cannot play it to your heart's content. However, if you love strategy games , then this could fit your bill. Personally, i like the game. As a battle realms lover, i have always loved outpacing my enemies in building our bases and farming resources, and these elements are all present in this game but with much, much more content. -On the flipside, game is buggy. It frequently crashes and sometimes requires me to restart my pc/laptop. I also found it a bit annoying that they require you to sign-up in their site, i mean for what purpose really? I sure do hope that the bugs will eventually be fixed.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Let me start by saying I am NOT a 4x player (infact I didn't even know what that was when I got this game), so this is coming from some one relatively new to the genre.FE:LH is the perfect example of an intimidating game.  There's just so much going on, so much custimization, so many options, and so much thought process that seems to need to go into every single turn to be successful, to a new player the whole experience can be more then a little overwhelming.Now that's not inherently a bad thing, obviously its not the game for you if your looking mindless fun, but if you enjoy a good strategic experience, a game having this much meat to it can be a really good thing, and can allow for a tremendous amount of depth and replay value.What it DOES mean, however, is that its absolutely crucial that the game has a top notch tutorial to ease a new player into the complexities the game has to offer.  There are various ways this can be accomplished, though my favorites have always been games which provide multiple missions/quests which start with only a small portion of the game available, and incremently add on more and more until by the end the player has had time to at least begin to understand each aspect of the game and is not putting it all together.Unfortunately, that is not the case with FE:LH.  The single player campaigns, while enjoyable, are not very informative or what I'd consider good learning tools.  Although there is a dedicated tutorial, its not very long, it mainly just shows you "how" to do a handful of things, then its over, providing very little information as to the why, and generaly leaving the players head spinning from the massive information dump.  It's reminsicent of some fighting games whose tutorials invovle asking you to do a bunch of a characters special moves, you do them, and then the tutorial is over.  You come away knowing these are things you can do, but not really knowing when or why you should do them, and it was all over so fast you probably won't even remember half of the moves once your in a match.Despite the lack of new player friendliness, I'm still giving this game a recommend.  Why?  Because I'm finding that if you're willing to endure a pretty terrible introductory experience and learn the concepts of the game the hard way, the actual game itself is quite well made and actually pretty darn fun.  I honestly feel that if this game had a quality tutorial this would be one of the better PC games out there, maybe even a must own.  As it is though, it takes a very special kind of dedicated player (or some one already familar with the 4x genre) to spend the hours learning things the hard way it takes to actually get to the fun part where you know what your doing and your making meaningful choices instead of random ones, so keep this in mind before purchasing.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												While I don't have many hours in this game at the time of the review, this is an addictive Civ5-like "just one more turn" 4X game. Set in a medieval fantasy world, Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes pits you against AI-controlled factions, each of which contain a Sovereign, the titular "Heroes" of the game. While there are preset sovereigns for you to choose from, you can create your own custom sovereign and choose which of 10 factions it belongs to. You can customize your army, as well, ranging from simple colors to starting equipment and whether or not they are mounted units. Keep in mind that adding stronger arms and armor to your troops will increase how much resources it will cost to create. You can, however, find Champions roaming around the world, seeking the aid of a Hero. Whenever you find a Champion, you can add them to your Sovereign's party or form parties of different units of your choice. There are multiple quests to perform, ranging from finding gold and resources to pillaging a dark lair full of spiders and necromancers. Combat has 2 forms; turn-based isometric view and standard Civ5-style quick attacks. If you choose the turn-based option, you are brought to a tactical overview of the battlefield and all the units within the party will appear on screen. Spells, abilities, and items can be used in battle, as well as many other spells, abilities, and items that can be used outside of battle. There is so much to do in this game that its hard to put down in this review without describing the whole game in detail. For $10 on sale, its worth the price for the base game. If you get hooked, the DLC adds more quests, enemies, loot, etc. If you like 4X games and the fantasy setting, give it a try!

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												UPDATED: Fallen Enchantress is a solid game, coming in at around 7.5/10 for me. The fantasy setting infused with magic can be a nice change of pace from the more reality based Civ5. The hero leveling, upgrade, and equipment mechanics are very nice. The devlop stories over time, complete with scars and injuries for defeats in battle. The city system isn't as flexible as Civ5, but is more tailored. While you can only build cities in select locations, each city can be customized from the start. first selecting the focus of the city, then the structures and "wonders" built. The multipul win conditions is a standard in 4x nowadays, but the victory conditions here are a little more satisfying.It is slightly buggy, but not game breakingly so. The menus and UI need more polish. The overall gameplay can get a little stale sometimes(IMO).The battles are a little more hands on with a turn based, grid battleground. I enjoy this more than just stacks of numbers duking it out on a world map. There is an auto-resolve option if you don't want to. It is what it is. You like it or you don't.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------(Not really a bad review, just raising a flag for an issue that some players may want to be aware of)Looking at my play time you may say "That's not enough for a proper review", and you're absolutely right. I may get around to playing it at some point, but not today. Here's why...This is not a review of the game, as I stopped before I made it to a menu. 3rd party DRM via Stardock Launcher needing a Stardock account. Not a real issue, pretty silly reason to give it a negative review. Only reason I've even writing this is because I have to. 3rd Party DRM is nowhere to be found on the store page. You can only figure it out by sifting through other reviews to find ones like this. If they had just listed this on the page, this review wouldn't even exist. Companies like Kalypso(Tropico series) have similar DRM, using their own launcher requiring an account. Meh, it's unwelcome and bothersome, but they're just trying to protect the software they worked hard on(lol, like it actually stops piracy). Weather it's due to an oversight or a shady nusniess model, it's the fact that they didn't list it that I'm rebeling to. Not cool to withold information until you have a persons money. Had I not got this for peanuts from HumbleBundle, I'd have returned it already.I'm sure this won't bother most, and it sounds like the game is pretty fun. I hope the game brings many hours of enjoyment to you. Just wanted to put this out there for those few of you it does matter too. Happy gaming!(P.S. It is a silly reason, so I've decided to play it anyway, but the 'thumbs down' remains until the game redeems itself)

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												I downloaded and played this game during the time period where they allowed it to be played for "Free". Would I pay 40$ for this game? Absolutely not. Would I pay 30$ for this game? Absolutely not. Would I pay 20$ for this game? Yes. This is based off of roughly 10 hours of play time. FIRST HOUR.The game has a somewhat clunky UI. It doesn't fully teach the player what to do when it comes to building a city or, better yet, maintaining a city properly once you level up a city and begin to expand. I don't care for a game holding my hand throughout but I feel with a game like this, you need to actually teach a player how to get their feet on the ground before thrusting them in the middle of a "Civilization-esque" RTS. I had no idea what to do for the first 45 minutes or so and even afterwards still had to sit and think how to do certain actions. Yes, I played through the tutorial. It did not help. Its very basic.CHARACTER/FACTIONS.I played with 3 different characters (roughly 3 hours apiece), 2 premade characters and one custom made "Aragorn-like" character that focused on using a bow and buffing his allies. This is where the game shines. Each character and faction is unique and interesting as well as potent if you expand and progress correctly. Creating a character took roughly 10 minutes and was enjoyable through the entire process. One of the things that is very different and seperates this game from others is that your hero levels up and becomes stronger. Skill trees are always a plus. QUESTING.One of the activities you can do in the game is do "Quest". Basically your hero walks into an Inn and someone says "Hey, go across the map and do this. If you succeed, I'll give you something." Then you do it. It's pretty basic but its something to do and it rewards your hero with neat little items and gear. WOULD I RETURN.I would buy the game (I've already deleted it once it regained the 40$ pricetag), if it dropped in price. I enjoyed the majority of my time and I'd love to go back and see how my character (which was directly based off my Dungeons and Dragons character) dealt with this ominous Black Gate area that was locked off from the rest of the map. This game is a STRONG 7/10. Its fun but it definitely has its problems that taint the total product. At the current price I can't recommend it. Wait for the price to drop or a sale THEN buy it.

												I thought this game was cool before it won an award. Well, at least I thought it had potential. At release it was pretty awful, but Stardock went to great lengths to fix it. The game is now a fun 4x with an injection of RPG goodness. The tactical part of combat can get slow while you watch you little guys lurch or waddle through their turns, but it's otherwise a sweet escape. If it goes on sale, buy it and all the DLC, and then set aside a few days of your life so that you may work through your addiction. I felt done with the game after about 100 hours, though there was plenty of content I didn't get to yet.

Posted: May 4, 2014
												Nice 4X with a well worked out combat system. I haven't found any game breaking bugs, only my PC crashing, but I recon that's just my PC. A nice unit creator let's really custommise your army to how you want, downside to this is that here arn't very many pre made units and the amount of weapons the limited. Equiping your hero has the same problems, it's nice that you can custommise your hero, but really I came across the same items over and over again. I haven't used the magic system a lot, so I can't give a real recommendation on that front, but from my experience it works well whit the two kinds of spells. Couple downside, one being that there is no Multiplayer, also to me a couple of hours to get the hang of it and a couple of balancing problems. Overall a fun game which your really benefit from some multiplayer.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												What Heroes of Mights and Magic IV, V and VI should have been.This game is a great merging of Heroes of Might and Magic III and Masters of Magic, two of the greatest games ever made in turn-based strategy.FE-LH is an addictive highly replayable game, where you can not only create your hero, but also his race or culture before even beginning to play the actual game.I think that FE-LH and Crusader Kings 1 and 2 are among the best games that came out since the year 2000, in all game categories. It is fun, chalenging, you can adjust difficulty level of the game, highly customizable game sessions (excellent tweaks you can do before creating a new game), decent amount of items for your heroes, decent amount of troops and monsters you can recruit, and so on.I highly recommend getting this game. One of the rare games that are worth playing again and again, as well as paying 50$ or less to get.Thumbs up to the designers!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This is all based on playing the free weekend.This game, Is like heroes of might and magic but with the city building side of civilisation. you are free to create your very own custom hero and build them however you want. For example you could have a warrior who grand slams everything into oblivion, or a mage who is a literal glass cannon. But theres more depth to the game, as you play you accumulate "fame" which at certain thresholds will give you the choice between two heroes, as you progress into the game, these heroes get more and more powerful to the point where you can get titled heroes such as the dragonborn.Tactical combat makes huge uses of tactics such as flanking and "swarming" where you surround units with your own and deal more damage and with a higher hit rate. Units are upgradable and certain units aka minor heroes don't have the same depth of customization as your main heroes but instead level up and gain traits like regular heroes.DRAGONS, DRAGONS, DRAGONS you can get dragons and they are huge and mean.Theres plenty of quest variety as well.Bottom line. If you enjoy games such as heroes of might and magic, civilization and Endless legend, then i highly recommend you give this game a try.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Fun game for those who like games such as Age of Wonders series and Civi series.  The game is mostly like Age of Wonders especially considering that you have a hero/champion to lead each army you create, however, it is also like Civilzation with the aspects of occupying parts of the map as your cities grow.  Another aspect I like is the world monsters such as dragons, I think that is pretty awesome compared to fighting with simple bandits.  It also uses a similar combat system to that of Age of Wonders 3 which requires you to fight in a tactical grid like movement and turns, think Heroes of Might & Magic in this aspect.All in all its a fun game and if you like the ones I mentioned you should certainly pick this one up too, if you haven't played them I recommend those also.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This game is a blast to play.  It has all the depth that I expect from a Stardock game, yet it isn't unmanageable.  My one complaint is how many times it has crashed on me so far; however, I blame that on my not-quite-up-to-par laptop.  The gameplay is enjoyable and there are many options within the game to help you manage your units and cities without feeling forced to direct EVERY unit.  The quests add great rewards and more things to do than just build and destroy.  The random events, which I did so enjoy in Gal Civ II, add many playback options.  You can craft your own world with its own story, heroes, and lore.  Really, you will get as much out of this game as you're willing to put into it.  I highly recommend this game!

Posted: January 11, 2015
												I downloaded and played this game during the time period where they allowed it to be played for "Free". Would I pay 40$ for this game? Absolutely not. Would I pay 30$ for this game? Absolutely not. Would I pay 20$ for this game? Yes. This is based off of roughly 10 hours of play time. FIRST HOUR.The game has a somewhat clunky UI. It doesn't fully teach the player what to do when it comes to building a city or, better yet, maintaining a city properly once you level up a city and begin to expand. I don't care for a game holding my hand throughout but I feel with a game like this, you need to actually teach a player how to get their feet on the ground before thrusting them in the middle of a "Civilization-esque" RTS. I had no idea what to do for the first 45 minutes or so and even afterwards still had to sit and think how to do certain actions. Yes, I played through the tutorial. It did not help. Its very basic.CHARACTER/FACTIONS.I played with 3 different characters (roughly 3 hours apiece), 2 premade characters and one custom made "Aragorn-like" character that focused on using a bow and buffing his allies. This is where the game shines. Each character and faction is unique and interesting as well as potent if you expand and progress correctly. Creating a character took roughly 10 minutes and was enjoyable through the entire process. One of the things that is very different and seperates this game from others is that your hero levels up and becomes stronger. Skill trees are always a plus. QUESTING.One of the activities you can do in the game is do "Quest". Basically your hero walks into an Inn and someone says "Hey, go across the map and do this. If you succeed, I'll give you something." Then you do it. It's pretty basic but its something to do and it rewards your hero with neat little items and gear. WOULD I RETURN.I would buy the game (I've already deleted it once it regained the 40$ pricetag), if it dropped in price. I enjoyed the majority of my time and I'd love to go back and see how my character (which was directly based off my Dungeons and Dragons character) dealt with this ominous Black Gate area that was locked off from the rest of the map. This game is a STRONG 7/10. Its fun but it definitely has its problems that taint the total product. At the current price I can't recommend it. Wait for the price to drop or a sale THEN buy it.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Nice 4X with a well worked out combat system. I haven't found any game breaking bugs, only my PC crashing, but I recon that's just my PC. A nice unit creator let's really custommise your army to how you want, downside to this is that here arn't very many pre made units and the amount of weapons the limited. Equiping your hero has the same problems, it's nice that you can custommise your hero, but really I came across the same items over and over again. I haven't used the magic system a lot, so I can't give a real recommendation on that front, but from my experience it works well whit the two kinds of spells. Couple downside, one being that there is no Multiplayer, also to me a couple of hours to get the hang of it and a couple of balancing problems. Overall a fun game which your really benefit from some multiplayer.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												This game is incredibly buggy and its manual is really badly written, spending much time on irrelevancies, but none on the important stuff. For example, I have no idea how to build roads and while the manual tells you it is important to do, it doesn't explain how to do it. The tutorial is laughably brief and pointless. Also, forget any kind of detail about all the supposedly nifty abilities your armies and champions get. There is a huge ingame "help" area, but it is jam packed full of fluff text and says nothing about how do actually do anything. I couldn't even search for roads, or find them listed.Edit: I also can't figure out how to give mounts to companions. I've a bucketload of them, but thre seems to be no way to give them to the heroes that need them the most.Bugwise, there is a constant bug that makes your borders vanish and which requires a restart of the game to fix. This happens every time you try to load up a saved game and is something that the developers have been made aware of ages ago, but chosen not to fix.Also, there are continuous random CTDs, the latest which completely hung my computer and required me to do a reboot of the machine. This game is a definite miss.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												I played this game when it first came out. It was buggy but it had a lot of potential. I decided to put it aside for a bit to give them time to fix some of the issues and add content. If you are a fanboy or part of the dev team you will likely disagree with me, but these are my opinions.The Good:-- A lot more content-- You can customize your hero-- Create and design your own troopsThe Bad:-- Gold is not hard to come by but shop prices would bankrupt Saudi Arabia-- When your heroes drop in combat but you win the battle, they are injured. Shops are incredibly hard to come by, the potions, found in shops, to heal your heroes are soo expensive it's better to kill all but 1 of your heroes and use disposable troops. Currently I have 5 heroes, 3 of them have at least 8 injuries, can't be healed. -- Sometimes when you attack a known force they are orders of magnitude more difficult than expected, for no reason, so sometimes when it should be an easy battle you will get wiped and you are not sure why.-- Sometimes when you pick up a quest it will have hidden defenders, and you are wiped. See above.-- Movement is tedious, slow, seems to be done deliberately just to slow down the game. -- The game play is very slow, over 700 turns to study a new magic skill, really ?!?!?The Ugly:-- Bugs. not just in gameplay but also in concept. It's frustrating because the game is there, they just ruined it with poor decisions.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												This game has one of the most boring and unhelpful tutorials that I have ever seen. Considering that a good amount of work seems to have gone into constructing it, this is actually kind of astounding. One of the most obvious problems is the very bland narration of the instructional videos that play before each section of the tutorial. Just thinking about that person talking is making me yawn.One more thing, I keep encountering a rather amusing glitch. Every time I start the game up, it pops up an error warning about my monitor resolution, but the resolution it lists is for my secondary monitor. After I close the error box, the game boots up, anyway, and on the correct monitor. It’s almost like the error message exists in it’s own little world, separate from the game’s actual start-up sequence.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												Edit 2/22:Having won my first game, I can definately say that the tactical battle system is very good. It's imporved upon, but I'm still somewhat iffy about the use of ranged fighters. Not only can a ranged fighter fling thier projectile clear across the battlefield, but obstructions mean nothing. A company of archer types can launch their volly though what should be completely solid objects. So there is no hiding from these units in the sense of using the environment.I'm on the fence about how fame is used as a gate mechanic for heroes, especially since it's very possible to blow though those gates and get high leveled heroes while your sovereign is either struggling in a remote location, or sitting in a city, busy in the administer role. While the old mechanic did make acquiring heroes a little easier and a lot more frequent, the heroes that you would run into weren't uber-powered without good reason.Something I find bothersome is the water, and that's somewhat a two-fold issue. The first part is that water, aside from rivers and swamps, are untraversable. There is no naval mechanic in the game as it stands. This leads to the second issue; the map. While the game has a basic grid, a hex system leads to more naturally shapped coastline. This means your land looks less boxy when looking at maps. But the major problem with the map is that no matter what, the map is all one continet or a group of subcontinets. Islands don't exist. This means that you will inevitablly come into contact with every rival faction if you haven't been killed already. It's not a case of *IF* as much as *WHEN*.I do like the political parts of the game. The AI isn't as stingy and stupid as it has been in other similar games. If the AI considers you a threat and it has no real way to stand up to you, that dominion will more than likely make contact with you and offer tribute. But sometimes the AI likes to brag about it's research in the most inappropriate ways. Having about 3/4ths of my tech trees completed, one dominion bragged about how it was reclaiming the ancient teachings of archery. I felt like this would be like North Korea bragging to Japan how awesome it is that they have computers that can now use 3.5in floppy disks. I sighed and ignored them, hellbent on fulfilling the requirements for the Spell of Making.--Edit 2/21:After about three hours of fiddling around with files and discovering that the prefs.ini file was not being acquired though the Steam client, I got to play the game as it was intended. As such, this is my honest review.TBS and 4x are a nice combination and I rather enjoy it. However, I think others might have some problems, I know I still kind of do. The AI is crazy difficult, so if you want a truly easy game to understand how to play, you need to set the difficulty to NOVICE, especially if this is your first time playing.I enjoy building armies of custom units, upgrading them accordingly, and rteaching heroes abilities to make them better in my conquests, but the game might get a little slowed with the citybuilding aspect. It can take a while to get a city going, and you really need to know the order in which you shoudl construct buildings before you really get into the nitty-gritty of the game.Combat is both fun and challenging at the same time. The challenge comes from the initiative feature, so it's important to pay close attention to your initiative bar before really doing anything foolish. So you really need to put consideration into timing, building and upgrading units and understanding the mechanics of battle.The storyline is pretty non-existant. The Cataclysm happened and the races are all scrambling about trying to get re-established as dominions. There are two side, Kingdom and Empire and to say either is a good guy or bad guy remains to be seen. It can be rather relative in this game. However being aligned with either of these two "superfactions" makes negotiations with the opposing "superfactions" a little more difficult because of an inherent mistrust. And just because you;re aligned with one dosen;t mean the other factions will be nice and leave you alone. No, if you're weak, they will smell the blood in the water and crush you just as well as the other side would.So with this said, after the hours long struggle to actually get this game to work, it's really not a bad game. It might be slow for some, but it has a ncie balance of elements that makes it fairly challenging and fun.--OriginalWow, just, wow. This is perhaps the most bugged-out game I have EVER tried. While I like the whole building a town and stuff, the game is bugged. The first problem is that you can't set the options. Second problem is that you can't save. I've been told that I need to access the Prefs.ini files, but those aren't apparent for me to change. There are people who have posted how to fix these difficulties my manipulating that .ini file, but perhaps it's Windows 10 and some compatability issues in which the game does not generate the prefs.ini file? If the game is this difficult in just the technical aspects, there's no way I can even suggest gameplay. If it's like it's orgin game, Elemental: War of Magic, you're totally SOL as that game had ALWAYS spawned all the factions next to each other.But do you realize the frustration of playing a game for 4ish hours, saving to get some sleep, and comming back to find that there is no save data?Another problem, if the game was bundled in the Ultimate Edition, a similar issue happens with fallen Enchantress; the options menu is locked the same way. But to make it worse, you can't zoom in any closer than the cloth map, or else the map is rendered as a grey field.
