content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												At first impression Fallen Enchantress is, for all intents and purposes, a fantasy-flavored Sid Meier's Civilization V clone. If you enjoyed Sid Meier's Civilization V and you enjoy fantasy elements in games you may well enjoy Fallen Enchantress. If you did not enjoy Sid Meier's Civilization V, or have not played Sid Meier's Civilization V because it didn't look like your kind of thing, or do not enjoy fantasy elements in games, you will probably not enjoy Fallen Enchantress. Personally, I did not enjoy Sid Meier's Civilization V and as such I proceeded not to enjoy Fallen Enchantress for much the same reasons.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												There is eseentially no AI at all. There might as well not even be other factions in the game. They do nothing. You can literally stand next to one of thier cities filled with units,  with one unit of ours, and they won't even come out to kill you.They might send a pioneer (non combat unit) to take over your undefended outposts, but that's it. This has got to be the weakest AI I've ever seen in any strategy game to date.It's too bad. The game feels like a pretty good framework for a 4x stratgy game. Really all it is, is you progressing through the tech tree and fighting the romaing monsters for kicks.The combat would be better if it was more tactical. It's grid based, Most units only move 2 squares in tactical combat which annoys you when you are fighting an enemy with archers who will all concentrate fire on your chanpion. You have to load him up with dodge equipment to kill the dumb AI that just sits there shooting you with arrows. They have mounted units that move more squares, but each faction only gets one flavor. You are _forced_ to use those against archers. Makes eveyr fight the same. Send mounted units to archers, and mop up with everything else. The AI always coincentrates fire on your champion, even if a unit on the board is a bigger threat.The unit progression makes one unit completely worthless against another. You pretty much find out what the most OP unit for a given faction is and just crank those out. Not much variety in combat that way. As you tech up, there really is no point in using anything but the best unit available.Some of the roaming monsters are rediculous. They move 5-6x before you even get an action, castin spells that instantly kill everyone. It makes it more of a puzzles to figure out where and how to get units resistant to whatever they cast, rather than a combt.Everything moves 2 squares at a time on the campaign map, making it a real pain the♥♥♥♥♥♥to hunt down all the worthless AI's pioneer spam. You can cast a force march to move 3 squares, but it can only be active on one unit at a time.In summary:The AI sucks hard and there were a few questionable desing decisions. It can be entertaining for a day or two, but it is no masterpiece.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												I am simply dumbfounded by the positive reviews for this game.  This game is an ongoing tragedy in what not to do as a game developer.  From the very beginning (in its first incarnation as Elemental: War of Magic) this game was doomed to failure.  From its horrid UI, to it's uninspired gameplay, vintage 1990's graphics, and abysmal balance--the game plays more like a college student's unfinished Unity 3D project than anything else.  How it has garnered fans of any kind is beyond me.I've always enjoyed games such as: Master of Magic, Disciples, Heroes of Might and Magic, and Age of Wonders, so, as a longtime supporter of Stardock/Bred Wardell, I was looking forward to their foray into the realm of Fantasy 4x.  One word sums up my experience:  Disappointment.  For the life of me, I don't understand how a game developer that produced Galactic Civilizations could produce something so unpolished and uninspired like Elemental/Fallen Enchantress.  It's like they didn't even research the genre--they just looked at Master of Magic and said, "Well, we can do better than that!".  The only problem with that point of view is that other/better developers had already made better fantasy 4x games, and had been pushing the genre forward for nearly a decade.Fallen Enchantress is a failed attempt at saving an aborted development project, nothing more.  A new development director was hired to rework the UI and add (i.e., "tack on") some new features--things like distict races, unique abilites, etc.--things that should have already been part of the initial design--in a desperate attempt to save an already-doomed game.  For some people, this was enough.  Gamers unfamiliar with the fantasy 4x genre liked what they saw, while veterans of the genre just asked the question:  "Why?  Why try to save this game?  Just let it go already."There are no bright spots with this game--not when you look around at all of the other, better fantasy 4x games that are out there.  As already mentioned, the main flaw with this game is that Stardock developed it in a vacuum, in isolation, and thought they were doing something monumental.  If this were the 1980s/early 1990s, they might have actually pulled it off.  Unfortunately, this game game out in the 2010+ era of PC games, and, quite frankly, PC gamers deserve better than this lukewarm dalliance with hubris.Also, if you actually compared this game to the Civilization series ..... shame on you.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												It feels and plays a lot like Civilization with a quest and individual hero system built in. The combat can be automatic outside of quests, like Civilization, or you can choose to battle turn-based style on a grid map (which I suck at in this game). The questing system is unique with this kind of game, and I really enjoy it. I played on easy and felt that the pacing was a little to fast as far as difficulty advancement, but this didn't hinder how fun it was. The quests have stories to go along that may involve getting new equipment, general, or army guys, which makes questing very worth it.I don't really like the tutorials, but as someone who still hasn't done it, I really suggest doing it. I can't seem to figure out how to get "guild points" as they don't seem to act the same as in Civilization even though it looks like it came from that game. There are little differences that if you have played or haven't played Civilization, it really makes the tutorial quite appealing.I was disappointed to have so many characters and only about three (way less than half; not even a quarter) were female. However, the female characters that were there had great backgrounds and characters, unlike other games where females are token characters / boring sex symbols.There is no customization except for naming stuff, and the buildings are automatically placed in order that you choose to build them.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
 If you are a fan of both Disciple and Sid Meier's Civilization series, then this is your dream.   It's about 65% Disciple and 35% Sid Meier's Civilization nicely combined.  The tactical battle is the same tpye of age of wonders and Disciple. The strategic side is like Heroes of Might and Magic wtih the Civilization tile output (resources) and city management.  The technology tree is a fantasy version of Civilization. However, it has three seperate categories. It's more like Beyond the Earth tech tree rather than Civilization 5 in that sense. Cons: When I said it's 65% of Disciple series, I also mean with its share of bugs and gliches. (well, I guess that's a part of               the Disciple franchise)          The DLCs are weak. I only got one so far. They certainly don't deserve the 4.99 price tag.            I do wish the tactical battle is on bar with the likes of King's bouty and Heroes of Might and Magic, the setting is                     too simple for the long run

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Of all my adventure games, this is by far my favorite. I love the graphics and gameplay. But I mostly like the scope. In my opinion, Endless Legend gets far too much hype. THIS is the game that inspired that one and others that came afterwards. The UI may be a bit rough around the edges but that's small potatoes compared to the game's engine. You have stacks of stuff to see, quest to pursue, and enemies to engage. I've never seen a game with so many different foes and characters save Age of Wonders III and the Warlock series. You can play the campaigns and have a wonderful time. But if you play a random map with random enemies and random other stuff, you're in for a real treat. Make sure to add all the DLCs.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												This is not a great game, far from it. It has several problems like dumb AI, diplomacy problems, path finding problems, balance problems, battle design problems, UI problems, graphic problems, and some more. Its a mashup game between Civilization and HoMM. It has Settlements, technologies trees, bonus terrains, diplomacy, etc just like Civilization. And it has heroes that can level up, buy equipments, cast spells and group up in a small army just like HoMM. But, because of the problems, its very below those 2 games.Still, its a very addictive game. It has so much potential that let you thinking why the hell Stardock decided to no deliver a more polished game. It could be a 9/10 game if it had done so. But, right now, its more of a 6.5/10 or 7/10 game. Still, Im having so much fun with this game that all the problems, although annoying at times, can easily be bypassed. Im currently with 20hours or so of /played and I think I will double it before unninstalling. And Im only unninstalling it because I have another 60 games or so to play before the 2014 Summer Sale.If you can look past the annoying problems, its a really fun game. But only if you can grab it in a sale. Its not worth the full price, since its not fully done.

Just don't bother, there are better games available.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												This game would be very awesome if not for a crippling bug.  You use outposts to control land area in the game.  However, if an enemy captures an outpost and you re-capture it, the zone of control will be smaller.  If this happens multiple times, the zone of control will be non-existent.  This bug has been in the game since before the expansion came out.  I stopped playing the first time because of the bug, and I've now uninstalled the game and given up on it because the developers don't seem to care about fixing it.Now, you can just destroy the outpost and rebuild it, but that also means rebuilding all of the addons associated with the outpost, which can get horribly time consuming.If the developer ever gets around to fixing this bug, let me know.  The game would be quite fun if not for that fatal flaw which leads to much frustration.Update 7/26/2016I have asked around to see if the bug is still in place with no response.  I reinstalled the game to give it another shot to see for myself.  While starting up a custom game, I noticed that many of the tooltips in the faction creation no longer work.  Saw other people with the same problem.  Posted about it on the forum.  No feedback for 5 days even though the post has been on the front page for the past 5 days.  Also, there are posts indicating that 2.0 is unplayable for many people.  I have not experienced this, but it seems that it's fairly prevalent.  Seems that things just keep getting worse for this game.  I cannot recommend it.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												A game that combines two of my favorite genres in gaming? Oh my. This game takes what was once known as Elemental: War of Magic and turns it into a game that truely is worthy of the Stardock label. This game so effortlessly combines the roles of empire making games with Dungeons and Dragons style heroic adventures you would be hard pressed to find a match for this game at any point in the history of video games. The graphics while not the most realistic are equally astounding in their artistic flavor, walls look imposing even from the god pov you are in for the entirety of the game. For instance my capital of Iphidar is surrounded by walls that put the walls of Constantinople to shame.The integration of magic in this game is so well done as to be second nature within five minutes of starting the game, casting city wide spells to boost productivity or city wide curses on your enemies to make their own citizens fight them has never been so easy or satisfying. Magic is litterally everywhere game. The world has stones littered through out it that act as focal points for magic and allow you to cast spels of greater potency or boost your already existing spells. Let us mot forget this is an empire building game as well. The governmental aspects of the game are what I have come to expect froma Stardock 4x game. They are in a word amazing. Extremely user friendly while allowing the player to govern all things a real government does i.e. taxes, building, army raising, ect. The interaction between in game states is simply amazing, the ai programmed for this game so realistically reacts to the players actions I am sometimes hard pressed to not believe there is another person controlling them. My opinion of this game is very high and am glad Stardock was able to rectify the utter disaster that was Elemental with this game and its predecessor Fallen Enchantress. I highly reccomend this game to all lovers of tactical planning and nation building and who have the patience to deal with the pace of turn based games.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Recommended for fans of TBS strategy and 4x games.  It plays similar to a cross between Civilization and Heroes of Might and Magic.  It is imperfect but may be the best fantasy 4x game out within the last few years.  Pros and cons listed in DETAIL below if you find them helpful.Pros:-Fun gameplay.  It delivers a quality 4x experience.  -Intuitive mechanics.  If you have played 4x games, you will grasp this game's concepts quickly.-Good tactical combat.  You can make a difference if you take command versus just autoresolve everything.  Tactical combat is not as strong as Heroes of Might and Magic or Age of Wonders 3, but it is a fun and useful part of the game.    -"Tame the land mechanic".  There are plenty of neutral monsters and quests to make expansion more than an uninteresting early-game land grab.  -Satisfying empire building.  Your cities level just like your heroes, and there are a variety of customizations options for each city.  This is a great mechanic!  Yet city management is streamlined enought that you don't get too bogged down late game with many cities.-Custom units.  You can make your own custom military units with their own characteristics once you've gotten the appropriate research and resoruces.  While more customization options would be nice, it is a very cool and welcome mechanic.   -Minimal waiting in between turns (in contrast to the long waits in Civilization 5).  The AI is thinking about its turn when you are taking yours, so the time it takes to execute their turn is minimal.  This is a big plus.Cons:-Graphics are ugly.  I suppose on the spectrum of 4x graphics, it is somewhere in the middle (with Dominions being ugliest and Civilization/Heroes of Might and Magic/ Age of Wonders 3 being pretty).  -Spells are bland and there are not enough of them.  I was never excited to get access to a new spell.  Spell research is also somewhat confusing - you get spells through a confusing combination of leveling your heroes and through research.  Master of Magic got spells exactly right and I wish more modern games would simply copy and improve on their model.  In MoM, you could make your own towns a paradise (all with nice little spell effects), you could summon awesome units, you could blight an enemy town with pestilence, chaos rifts, etc (all visualized nicely), you could plunge the world into eternal night, and you simply researched each spell individually and intuitively.  FE has fewer and less exciting options.-Hero advancement is similarly bland.  Although there was an extensive list of traits to acquire, I was never excited to gain a new level with my hero because none of the traits were that interesting.  Contrast this to the excellent system in the Heroes of Might and Magic series.  In that series, getting Grandmaster Fire Mage or even Basic Logistics was always exciting because the skills were useful and interesting.  This is not so in FE sadly.   -Not enough fantasy creatures on your side.  You may get about 3 uninteresting summoning spells (only 1 of which is good) that are limited to 1 summoned creature per spell per hero.  So you will not lead a shambling horde of zombies and skeletons or demons like you could in Master of Magic or Dominions.  A few races also have access to 1 fantasy creature that they can recruit directly from towns (and you can even customize, which is cool but really limited).  If you capture the right location on the map or complete a long questline, you may get a dragon (one) as well.  Humanoid troops are nice fodder and need to be there, but they should be 60-70% of your army, not 98% of it.  The reason people want to play this type of game instead of Civilization is specifically FOR the fantasy creatures and the spells!  -Races are bland.  For some reason, Stardock departed from fantasy conventions of men, elves, orcs, dwarves, etc.  Instead, they have races that are elf-like and dwarf-like and orc-like, but they are  more humanoid and less interesting.  Except for a few structures and traits, they all play similarly.  Again I must compare to Master of Magic where each race had its own unique units and tech tree.  Also compare to HoMM 3 or 5 - each race felt unique and played differently.  -Weak, uninteresting quest items.  In spite of a lot of questing, I seemed to only get bland, weak, and uninteresting reward items.  I would always replace them from the shop whenever I researched the right tech.  -Furthermore, there is no mechanic to make your own powerful items.  Master of Magic, Dominions, and to a lesser extent Age of Wonders all got this right.  I should be able to expend considerable magic resources to make a great artifact for my heroes to use.  Whether that's a sword that raises  slain foes as zombie minions, armor that makes the wearer ethereal, a horn that empowers the troops, or a staff that disintegrates the enemy, this mechanic is sorely missing in FE.  -There is little penalty for heroes defeated in combat.  They simply get a tiny permanent debuff (typically of little to no consequence) and respawn the next turn at low health in your nearest town.  While there should be some mechanism to retrieve your fallen sovereign or save your heroes with extraordinary magic, I personally prefer both my heroes and my enemy's heroes to die and stay dead under most circumstances.  Heck, in Dominions not only did dead characters stay dead (albiet with the possibility of resurrection or magical unlife), they could get significant battle wounds even if they survived victorious combat.  In Heroes of Might and Magic, the defeated hero would abandon your cause entirely.                     -Poor optimization.  The game chugged on my old computer to the point of unplayability mid-game.  It still gets a little chunky on my new Alienware hotrod.  For a game with such primitive 3D graphics, that should not happen!Conclusion:  Recommended to fans of the genreThis game is a good, fun empire builder.  As an empire builder, it is better than Age of Wonders III but not quite as good as Civilization 5.  Unfortunately the fantasy elements (spells, hero advancement, fantasy creatures, and races) are quite inferior to games like Master of Magic, Heroes of Might and Magic, Age of Wonders III, and Dominions.  However, the game is greater than the sum of its parts and a good empire builder with (albiet bland) fantasy elements is still a worthy part of a strategy fan's library.  Though I've listed a lot of cons, I really did have a good time with the game.  Its shortcomings didn't bother me until well after I had gotten my money's worth of entertainment.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Fallen Enchantress is an awesome 4X turn-based strategy/sorta-RPG game. One thing that I enjoy about the game is that it’s VERY different from other fantasy 4X games in a number of key ways.First, it takes place many years after the world was devastated by a war of magic – it’s essentially a post-apocalyptic fantasy world. Virtually everything concerning magic and technology had been lost (technology in this case being the standard medieval-level of weaponry and military tactics). You’re leading a rag-tag group of survivors to build your faction’s first city and begin to rebuild. Of course, you were chosen as leader because you are one of the only people remaining who can wield magic.Secondly, there’s none of the standard Orcs, Goblins, Elves, Dwarves, blah blah blah that have become standard fare for fantasy games. The races are all (with the exception of Men) completely original, as are most of the bestiary that pose a constant threat outside of the safety of your cities. However, the game makes all of the new races and creatures easy to understand with a very thorough and easy-to-access online guide that seamlessly integrates lore and story with game mechanics. Want to know what the Trogs can do before you play as them? Just hover over the attribute marker reading TROG BLOOD in the character roster and see their benefits and disadvantages. Got an army of Brood Hunters headed for a city? Just click on the army on the map and click their profile to read all about them and see their stats.Also, virtually everything is customizable. Make new leaders, new factions, new units. Just researched Warg Riding and want to make some cavalry? Just pop into the unit design screen and design them, what armor they wear and what weapons they carry, etc. Just make sure you have a source of Wargs handy – depending on what weaponry and armor you give your units, you may need a variety of resources (metal, horses/Wargs, magic crystal, etc) to create them. These can be found on the map and brought under control of your cities by building on them.All-in-all, it’s a great game that slipped under the radar to a certain extent.

												This turn-based 4x game is set in a fantasy world.  The player represents a faction leader who grants special abilities to the race he controls.  The leaders have backstories and special attributes which make picking a leader about more than just selecting a color for your tokens.  The real focus of gameplay are the heroes which level up and gain power over the course of the game.  The game is a bit buggy, but I still love it and I've put in over 400 hours so far.  Probably the best comparison would be Master of Magic or Age of Wonders.

												Civ fanatics look here. This is Civ on crack. This is one of my favorite games of all time that I can just fall back on an enjoy endless hours of game play. You can take your hero, recruit more heroes and go on epic quests or just take over the world militarily. You can win by crafting the the most epic spell, win by diplomacy, win by kicking the♥♥♥♥♥♥our of everyone or win by achieving the hardest end quest. I think one of the coolest parts of this game is the ability to create and customize your own army. You can pick what kind of armor and weapons it has, the gender, size. Just a whole lot of options. If you are looking for a game in your library that will keep you entertained for years, pick up this game. It's just fantastic.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												This is an excellent combo of empire building and RPG.  I did read previous reviews and I can see the Civ 5 comparison and it is valid, there are similarities with city building & tech trees, but it has the extra dimension of having heroes to find loot, do quests, upgrade weapons, armour and skills and it works brilliantly.  It's not as easy as some reviewers claim (unless you save the game before battles and reload if you lose, which I think takes away the fun) but if you like turn based combat you will love it.  You learn to pick your battles, there are no shortage of heroes so if you lose one its not too bad, they do heal after they 'die' but in the early game it does limit what you can do and you will fall behind your rivals. I do like the fact that, unlike most turn based combat, your armies can have up to 9 units so you have a mix of defensive, ranged and attacking units.  Although set in a Fantasy style world I am avoiding magic (alright I do have a healing spell) and with my second attempt (on default settings) I am  managing to hold my own but not always in the lead. I can see many different ways to win, the maps are randomly generated each time, the difficulty setting is variable, the diplomacy is better than Civ 5 and I am looking forward to many happy hours of game play.   I would recommend a look on YouTube before you buy and if you think you might like it you definately will.  I havent seen a clip yet where they are having as much fun as I am now... 9/10

												At the discounted price, this game is a golden opportunity, even for those who aren't addicted to 4x games.  You will get more than $10 of value just playing the scenarios and following the storyline, and there are few games that are as replayable. 												I bought Elemental when it first came out and well, it was pretty bad. The one thing good about Elemental was the unique gameplay. It was fun. Fallen Enchatress is no different. The interactivity of research unlocking items that you can put on your troops and heroes so they can be better defended and better armed is really neat. All in all, this is a great strategy game with a heaping of RPG and the partial city system of civilization but not so complicated. REcommended highly.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												I recommend it mostly to all who didn't play previous Fallen Enchantress game (legendary heroes brings some changes regarding champion leveling and fame resource). It's basicaly a Civilization meets Age of wonders - utilizing many good aspects from those kind of games without flawing any of them... well except AI - which is terrible at this point. To be more specific You will see many AI glitches which really shouldn't happen in finished product which is more frustrating considering the fact that this game is 3rd installment of the series. But to make long story short...Goodies are- good mix of RPG with Civi like kingdom strategy with tactical battles juiced with skills and spells- great army design system which lets you create your own units using available weapons, enchantments etc. and pack of perks to choose from- overall nice, rewarding gameplay- if anyone played Civilization before it's almost hop in and play type of game with only some minor aspects You have to learn aboutBad- terrible AI aflicting both tactical battles and overall enemy strategies (I played on above average difficulty and sadly AI shown no signs of any strategy at all)- no good tutorial/help book, there's internet but still... remember detailed Civilopedia with every possible aspect of game at least reasonably mentioned and described? Well prepare for big black holes in FELH help book - some ppl might get ofended by graphics quality in army design closeup mode, I mean it's 2013 and again it's 3rd installment of the game c'mooonNote to the producer:Aside from gameplay aspects - marketing/business approach which consists of making minor changes and selling them as another game (Legendary Heroes are infact patched Fallen Enchantress) instead of letting them as update which in fact they are is uncool, very uncool.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Fallen Enchantress, formerly known as Elemental: War of Magic has come a long way since its shaky release back in 2010. Legendary Heroes is the first expansion to Fallen Enchantress and brings with it a slew of new features, fixes, and content that isn’t going to win over any new fans but dedicated fans will welcome openly. I’m not going to cover the base game, as I will assume you are familiar with the general gameplay of Fallen Enchantress. If you’re green, I’d strongly suggest you catch up and read my initial review of the game. Basically Elemental is a turn based strategy game that balances a role playing game alongside deep empire building. Of course what expansion wouldn’t be complete without new races, monsters, quests, spells, and equipment? The new stuff just keeps piling in and you’ll only discover all of it after you play a couple games. Keep in mind that Fallen Enchantress is a day killer, where you will suffer from ‘just one more turn’ until it is 3AM. It’s refreshing to see that Stardock has put a ton of thought into new content for the game, and even after dozens of hours I still haven’t even scratched the surface. Maybe it’s due to the fact that they also added a new map size - “huge”. This lets you play longer, more epic games where you are commanding armies across vast landscapes. There is so much to Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes that it is really tough to describe, especially since it kind of mashes several genres together. I can say that you won’t be disappointed with the changes they have made and the content they have added. Personally I’m used to Stardock games evolving as I play them, so Legendary Heroes is a welcome addition to the Elemental stable. The expansion makes it look better, feel more organic, and balances the whole experience for the player. If you’re one of those people who bought Fallen Enchantress on a Steam sale and are looking for a reason to actually play the game, look no further - grab Legendary Heroes and carve out an afternoon to really sink your teeth into the game. If you felt burned by Elemental and the lackluster release a couple years ago, I urge you to get back on the horse and ride this bad boy into the sunset because Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes proves that Stardock isn’t giving up on this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												This is an excellent combo of empire building and RPG.  I did read previous reviews and I can see the Civ 5 comparison and it is valid, there are similarities with city building & tech trees, but it has the extra dimension of having heroes to find loot, do quests, upgrade weapons, armour and skills and it works brilliantly.  It's not as easy as some reviewers claim (unless you save the game before battles and reload if you lose, which I think takes away the fun) but if you like turn based combat you will love it.  You learn to pick your battles, there are no shortage of heroes so if you lose one its not too bad, they do heal after they 'die' but in the early game it does limit what you can do and you will fall behind your rivals. I do like the fact that, unlike most turn based combat, your armies can have up to 9 units so you have a mix of defensive, ranged and attacking units.  Although set in a Fantasy style world I am avoiding magic (alright I do have a healing spell) and with my second attempt (on default settings) I am  managing to hold my own but not always in the lead. I can see many different ways to win, the maps are randomly generated each time, the difficulty setting is variable, the diplomacy is better than Civ 5 and I am looking forward to many happy hours of game play.   I would recommend a look on YouTube before you buy and if you think you might like it you definately will.  I havent seen a clip yet where they are having as much fun as I am now... 9/10

												I bought this game looking for a fantasy turn based strategy game. I use to really like playing age of wonders shadow magic, and this game seemed to kind of resemble it. So I went ahead and bought it, well to my surprise I found this game to both be well polished and very fun to play. Combat- you have the option of auto-resolve which I find to be good when you know you are unlikely to lose a unit.There is also the option of doing the battle yourself, which is what I normally do ( it seems when you auto-resolve they don't use your units abilities). The game loosely reminds me of civilization, you have 3 trees that you can choose from to develop via research,civilization, warfare, and magic. Each has its own benefits, and so it's sometimes tough choice as to which one to develop first.I don't do reviews so it's pretty short and to the point, but overall I would give this game a solid 8.5 for the Turn Based Stragey game class.

												Decent fantasy 4x game with lots of replay value. Some of the factions don't feel as distinct as others, but you can create your own faction and starting heroes so it's a good compromise. The magic enhances the game quite a bit, manually designing your units doesn't feel as deep as Galactic Civ games, but it still plays an important strategic role.Overally, I feel like I had a lot of fun with this game, spent quite a lot of time on it, and played almost every faction. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												This game has a great concept. Despite its mid-90s graphics, the mix of strategy and RPG, the way you can customize your heroes and your units, the interesting quests and monsters - all of that is timeless and shines in spite of the graphics. HOWEVER - I cannot recommend this game because of how incredibly buggy and poorly polished it is. This game takes more RAM and CPU resources than games far more technologically advanced (i.e. Civ 5, XCOM, Endless Space). It crashes every 3-5 turns. It often freezes during a battle, and reloading a prior save doesn't help. Lastly, reloading saves reliably crashes the game on my computer, and again, I run far more advanced games than this with no problems. I've asked the developer for support and troubleshooting and it never helped. Unlike other games that started out buggy but was fixed and smoothed with patches (i.e. Divinity Original Sin), this game has essentially been abandoned by its developers and I have not seen any fixes for years. What could have been a great game has been ruined by bugs.

Also, they have tried something new - and I must say, some of these new things I like. I am not overly fond of art style but the game as it is now is enjoyable. Also, diplomacy is not bad (definitely much better than some other games, e.g. Endless series).I would really like at this point though if Stardock developed an incremental sequel to this instead of dubious Sorcerer King title.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes is an immersive fantasy themed strategy game and a significant improvement over the earlier Elemental: Fallen Enchantress version. I’ve been a fan of sword and sorcery based 4x titles since SimTex Software cranked out their classic Masters of Magic in 1994. Putting this game on an “enjoyment continuum” of recent titles, I’d place it a notch behind Age of Wonders III, on a par with Endless Legends and well ahead of Worlds of Magic.The interface is mostly intuitive and a few minutes with the tutorial will allow even 4x novices to jump into the game and learn the finer nuances as they play. The RPG elements are well-integrated and detailed enough to give gameplay a coherent narrative. The visuals are a mixed bag with the locales and topography offering a nice board game vibe but the character art coming off as an unsatisfying derivative of 90’s manga. The sounds and music are neither annoying nor memorable. I have not encountered any performance problems running the game on a two-year-old computer with a 3.4 GHZ Intel processor, 12GB RAM and an NVIDIA GT640 video card.It’s a full price title made all the more sweet if you can bag it on sale.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												I got this game for 10$ cad on sale, and for that price it no doubt good.  The game does get repetitive and the AI is not good at all.  You can simply turtle through the game even on the 2nd highest difficulty. I haven't bothered with the highest difficulty yet, but I'm sure it is the same because the AI simply gets more resource boosts.  The devs also seem to have a habit of rehashing their games a lot, this being the 3rd iteration of Elemental.  I have not played Elemental or Fallen Enchantress, but I have read that they are almost the same as FE: Legendary Heroes.  I got this game at 75% so I was not disappointed, at 10$ there is still ample play and it is a good deal, but in the long run I would rather play Master of Magic, which seemed to have a bit more depth and more variety of creatures and magic. Edit: This game is no where near as good as Age of Wonders III. I will still leave a positive recommendation because I got this game for 10$ on sale, and because they game isn't completely horrible.  The ai  never seems to try and attack and that is the biggest problem with this game.

content:

												I am a novice in the 4X genre. I first played a Civilization game (Call to Power) 15 years ago, but haven't explored the genre much since. As such, I cannot confidently speak to if Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes meets/exceeds the expectations of fully initiated fans of games like these, or how it compares to any other benchmark titles in the genre's history. All I can say is that I love this game, and I am definitely going to be looking for more games of this genre.   I love the fantasy medieval styling, and the gameplay (magic mechanics, designing units, outposts, diplomacy, empire-mangement, heroes, quests, etc) are all really interesting.   Can't wait to see more content for this game. Sequels, expansions?

content:
Posted: July 4, 2013
												This is the Exp to Fallen Enchantress and in my opinion a needed element to the original game. Not only does it add two new races (Humans: Capitarians-Merchants, Fallen: Urxen- Ind Armies) and a new leveling system for all the heroes, along with more monsters, and magic to cast into the world. For anyone not familiar with Fallen Enchantress, it is a TBS 4x game with generals who level up similar to a RPG system. The strength of your empire and random encounters determine how many heroes you have to help lead your army. Anyone who likes RPG's and city builders, should try Fallen Enchantress, and this DLC will add a lot of richness to the orginal game's experience.

												Let me get this straight right away, I like this game, it is a deep and interesting title which has massive replayability and fun unit design. However it is somewhat buggy and lacks many diplomacy options which we see in other games.Lets start with the pro's:Fun and interesting combatGood variety of unitsUNIT CUSTOMISATION - I LOVE THISinteresting hero systemNice animations in diplomacy scenesReasonably polished gameFun questing system that you don't see in many similar gamesNice faction creationNice sovereign creationNice spells which can be cast both in and out of combatCon'squite buggy - however they have patched several of the bugs recentlySometimes in combat UI it is unclear which unit you are controllingSomewhat irrational AI opponentsLimited diplomacy options - can't sell cities and treaties are limitedSometimes the enemy can gain a massive boost in power for no apparent reasonVery similar to other fantasy strategy gamesLimited number of quests from what I've seen - I've seen the same quests on different levelsConclusion:I really enjoy this game, it has fun combat, decent AI and enjoyable strategy elements however the bugs are a massive pain and the diplomacy options - or lack thereof - are very annoying.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Score: 87Concept: Civilization Style Fantasy GamePros: Very Technical, High Functionality, Tons of Features, Very Cool WorldCons: Tired Graphics, Wanted Bigger MapsEvery Single time I see a "Civ clone" I'm intrigued and have to try it out. But make no mistake this game is no Civ clone. It has the formula that Civilization has, but manages to completely make a new, fresh, and original game. Also, this game is definitely NOT Warlock, which(I love) IS a Civ clone. Anyways, to rewind a bit, Fallen Enchantress has been out on Steam for over a year at this point. I've been waiting for some sort of commentary on it and nothing. I has a Metascore of 80, which isn't bad, but I'm not investing $40 in a wild card. Well I knicked it in the Steam Summer Sale for $7.49 and after several hours am proud to say its worth the full price. This is a game that I will be playing for years to come until a sequel is released.Right off the bat I found myself comparing it to the hallmark in this style of gaming. And for the life of me I was finding loads of features in this game THAT SHOULD BE STANDARD. For example, when you research new technologies and unlock new equipment you can either use the default units that are created or... you can MAKE YOU OWN UNITS. This is one of the coolest features I've ever seen. You can customize virtually everything. Sure there are the cosmetic customizations, but you will spend so much time making the perfect hero, unit, army, and city. Oh, this is cool, you can specialize your city as you level up. Do you want it to be a military city? How about a research enclave? Or how about just a standard town?the game has eliminated worker units so everything that they would do, now you the player can do by hand. This is such a relief. I hated having a dozen workers take forever to build a road from city A to city B. In Civ it can take ten to fifteen seconds to load each turn because there are so many units on the board that the game has to move, in a game with thousands of turns you can spend hours just waiting. That problem is gone with Fallen Enchantress as there are far less units on the map.The game does a great deal more. You have quests, and monsters, magic, and more. The part of the game that gets a bit tired might be the combat. When you get into combat with an enemy it takes you down to the field and you play out the battle. I like this. However, I died so much. And if you get dragged into a battle that is clearly over your head you have to play out losing unless you have the flee 'skill'. In this respect it will start to feel like Fire Emblem. If I lose one of my heroes, I'll quit the game and restart from a previous save point. Sound familiar?Second Look: For those of you that don't really play this genre I don't really see too many picking this up. It may interest you if you like a good fantasy game, but it's complexities would turn away most people new to this genre. Where one person might see a game full of ways to control the flow of the game, another person might see a game bogged down with too many mechanics that get in the way of the core game.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I bought this game looking for a fantasy turn based strategy game. I use to really like playing age of wonders shadow magic, and this game seemed to kind of resemble it. So I went ahead and bought it, well to my surprise I found this game to both be well polished and very fun to play. Combat- you have the option of auto-resolve which I find to be good when you know you are unlikely to lose a unit.There is also the option of doing the battle yourself, which is what I normally do ( it seems when you auto-resolve they don't use your units abilities). The game loosely reminds me of civilization, you have 3 trees that you can choose from to develop via research,civilization, warfare, and magic. Each has its own benefits, and so it's sometimes tough choice as to which one to develop first.I don't do reviews so it's pretty short and to the point, but overall I would give this game a solid 8.5 for the Turn Based Stragey game class.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												A mix of CIV and Heroes of Might and Magic. The maps can be enormous and will take you 20+ hours to complete. There are also smaller maps that, of course, are much less time intensive.With a mix of empire building, research, resource management (yes, you can run out of iron to build those awesome units, but so can the ai) mixed with RPG leveling of your sovereign and champions, there is a lot you can do. That said, the pace can be slow. You have options on the customization of creating a world, but I kind of like the slower pace as my units are not obsolete in 10 turns. Research basically allows you to upgrade armor, weapons, etc. of basic units. Not like CIV where you have spearmen, pikemen, etc. They are essentially the same, with different buffs. You can give them fire resitent cloaks, magic necklaces etc. However, it will cost you more in resources. In a strange twist, it is more expensive to buy things for your heroes! The AI is pretty decent, but not that good at measuring army strengths and weaknesses. This can lead the AI to wasting expensive troops against their counters. Afterwords, you can mop them up as they have little armor.Overall, it is engaging and does have that "one more turn" thing. It deserves an 8 of 10.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												At the discounted price, this game is a golden opportunity, even for those who aren't addicted to 4x games.  You will get more than $10 of value just playing the scenarios and following the storyline, and there are few games that are as replayable.  Wander aimlessly and explore every dark nook (set world creation to lots of monsters and wildlands), or min/max in your drive to conquer the world (decent AI at the higher levels, and these developers have historically been dedicated to improving the sophistication of their games).  Fantasy, role playing, strategy, exploration--there's something in this blend for just about everyone (heh, unless you are dedicated to twitch gaming).

Posted: February 8, 2014
												I recommend it mostly to all who didn't play previous Fallen Enchantress game (legendary heroes brings some changes regarding champion leveling and fame resource). It's basicaly a Civilization meets Age of wonders - utilizing many good aspects from those kind of games without flawing any of them... well except AI - which is terrible at this point. To be more specific You will see many AI glitches which really shouldn't happen in finished product which is more frustrating considering the fact that this game is 3rd installment of the series. But to make long story short...Goodies are- good mix of RPG with Civi like kingdom strategy with tactical battles juiced with skills and spells- great army design system which lets you create your own units using available weapons, enchantments etc. and pack of perks to choose from- overall nice, rewarding gameplay- if anyone played Civilization before it's almost hop in and play type of game with only some minor aspects You have to learn aboutBad- terrible AI aflicting both tactical battles and overall enemy strategies (I played on above average difficulty and sadly AI shown no signs of any strategy at all)- no good tutorial/help book, there's internet but still... remember detailed Civilopedia with every possible aspect of game at least reasonably mentioned and described? Well prepare for big black holes in FELH help book - some ppl might get ofended by graphics quality in army design closeup mode, I mean it's 2013 and again it's 3rd installment of the game c'mooonNote to the producer:Aside from gameplay aspects - marketing/business approach which consists of making minor changes and selling them as another game (Legendary Heroes are infact patched Fallen Enchantress) instead of letting them as update which in fact they are is uncool, very uncool.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Mmmm, a little on the fence with this one.  If I would give it a number on 10, I would give it a 6.  Although I like it, this game could have been awesome if the bugs had been fixed and it had been optimized.  Here is a description:Bugs: Through my 14 hour playthrough, I had two crash to desktops.  Also had a game breaking bug that I had to work around during a battle.  An enemy warlock would try to summon a creature that would never appear.  Reloading the game 3 times did not resolve it.  The game would just sit there, with nothing happening for 3min before I closed it through windows.  The only way I could fix this was to try to kill the warlock before he tried to summon his creature.  Worked fine after but that's not normal.Performance:  This was the most nagging aspect of the game and what I believe soured my experience.  On a normal map, the scrolling would not be fluid and clicks felt laggy.  It doesn't make sense that my computer would struggle with this game.  See, I have an 3ghz i7 processor with 6gigs of ram and a GTX670.  Civilization 5 works perfectly fine and runs a millions times better than this game.  Civ5 is a much more beautiful, bigger and CPU/GPU intensive game than Fallen Enchantress.Gameplay: So is the game fun?  Yes, it is.  It reminds me of an old Magic game by Microprose back in the old dos days of computers.  It is a mix of Civilisation where you create cities, build and manage them while you conquer the world in a way that best fits your style.  And then battle enemies with your armies of heroes and units that gain experience and level on a grid battlefield a little like Might and Magic: Heroes, but better since good unit placement is actually important. Graphics: They are subpar at best by this day and age.  I thought the textures looked dull and certain equipment items for your heroes were blurry and I sometimes could barely make out what they were just by looking.Audio:  I thought that the audio was good, nothing stood out here.  The music was fine, not excellent.Can I recommend it?  Yes.  Although I can't help but think what this game could have been.  A classic if the studio would have spent a little more time polishing it.Would I have played longer than 14 hours if the experience was better?  Completely!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Recommended for fans of TBS strategy and 4x games.  It plays similar to a cross between Civilization and Heroes of Might and Magic.  It is imperfect but may be the best fantasy 4x game out within the last few years.  Pros and cons listed in DETAIL below if you find them helpful.Pros:-Fun gameplay.  It delivers a quality 4x experience.  -Intuitive mechanics.  If you have played 4x games, you will grasp this game's concepts quickly.-Good tactical combat.  You can make a difference if you take command versus just autoresolve everything.  Tactical combat is not as strong as Heroes of Might and Magic or Age of Wonders 3, but it is a fun and useful part of the game.    -"Tame the land mechanic".  There are plenty of neutral monsters and quests to make expansion more than an uninteresting early-game land grab.  -Satisfying empire building.  Your cities level just like your heroes, and there are a variety of customizations options for each city.  This is a great mechanic!  Yet city management is streamlined enought that you don't get too bogged down late game with many cities.-Custom units.  You can make your own custom military units with their own characteristics once you've gotten the appropriate research and resoruces.  While more customization options would be nice, it is a very cool and welcome mechanic.   -Minimal waiting in between turns (in contrast to the long waits in Civilization 5).  The AI is thinking about its turn when you are taking yours, so the time it takes to execute their turn is minimal.  This is a big plus.Cons:-Graphics are ugly.  I suppose on the spectrum of 4x graphics, it is somewhere in the middle (with Dominions being ugliest and Civilization/Heroes of Might and Magic/ Age of Wonders 3 being pretty).  -Spells are bland and there are not enough of them.  I was never excited to get access to a new spell.  Spell research is also somewhat confusing - you get spells through a confusing combination of leveling your heroes and through research.  Master of Magic got spells exactly right and I wish more modern games would simply copy and improve on their model.  In MoM, you could make your own towns a paradise (all with nice little spell effects), you could summon awesome units, you could blight an enemy town with pestilence, chaos rifts, etc (all visualized nicely), you could plunge the world into eternal night, and you simply researched each spell individually and intuitively.  FE has fewer and less exciting options.-Hero advancement is similarly bland.  Although there was an extensive list of traits to acquire, I was never excited to gain a new level with my hero because none of the traits were that interesting.  Contrast this to the excellent system in the Heroes of Might and Magic series.  In that series, getting Grandmaster Fire Mage or even Basic Logistics was always exciting because the skills were useful and interesting.  This is not so in FE sadly.   -Not enough fantasy creatures on your side.  You may get about 3 uninteresting summoning spells (only 1 of which is good) that are limited to 1 summoned creature per spell per hero.  So you will not lead a shambling horde of zombies and skeletons or demons like you could in Master of Magic or Dominions.  A few races also have access to 1 fantasy creature that they can recruit directly from towns (and you can even customize, which is cool but really limited).  If you capture the right location on the map or complete a long questline, you may get a dragon (one) as well.  Humanoid troops are nice fodder and need to be there, but they should be 60-70% of your army, not 98% of it.  The reason people want to play this type of game instead of Civilization is specifically FOR the fantasy creatures and the spells!  -Races are bland.  For some reason, Stardock departed from fantasy conventions of men, elves, orcs, dwarves, etc.  Instead, they have races that are elf-like and dwarf-like and orc-like, but they are  more humanoid and less interesting.  Except for a few structures and traits, they all play similarly.  Again I must compare to Master of Magic where each race had its own unique units and tech tree.  Also compare to HoMM 3 or 5 - each race felt unique and played differently.  -Weak, uninteresting quest items.  In spite of a lot of questing, I seemed to only get bland, weak, and uninteresting reward items.  I would always replace them from the shop whenever I researched the right tech.  -Furthermore, there is no mechanic to make your own powerful items.  Master of Magic, Dominions, and to a lesser extent Age of Wonders all got this right.  I should be able to expend considerable magic resources to make a great artifact for my heroes to use.  Whether that's a sword that raises  slain foes as zombie minions, armor that makes the wearer ethereal, a horn that empowers the troops, or a staff that disintegrates the enemy, this mechanic is sorely missing in FE.  -There is little penalty for heroes defeated in combat.  They simply get a tiny permanent debuff (typically of little to no consequence) and respawn the next turn at low health in your nearest town.  While there should be some mechanism to retrieve your fallen sovereign or save your heroes with extraordinary magic, I personally prefer both my heroes and my enemy's heroes to die and stay dead under most circumstances.  Heck, in Dominions not only did dead characters stay dead (albiet with the possibility of resurrection or magical unlife), they could get significant battle wounds even if they survived victorious combat.  In Heroes of Might and Magic, the defeated hero would abandon your cause entirely.                     -Poor optimization.  The game chugged on my old computer to the point of unplayability mid-game.  It still gets a little chunky on my new Alienware hotrod.  For a game with such primitive 3D graphics, that should not happen!Conclusion:  Recommended to fans of the genreThis game is a good, fun empire builder.  As an empire builder, it is better than Age of Wonders III but not quite as good as Civilization 5.  Unfortunately the fantasy elements (spells, hero advancement, fantasy creatures, and races) are quite inferior to games like Master of Magic, Heroes of Might and Magic, Age of Wonders III, and Dominions.  However, the game is greater than the sum of its parts and a good empire builder with (albiet bland) fantasy elements is still a worthy part of a strategy fan's library.  Though I've listed a lot of cons, I really did have a good time with the game.  Its shortcomings didn't bother me until well after I had gotten my money's worth of entertainment.

												I got this game for 10$ cad on sale, and for that price it no doubt good.  The game does get repetitive and the AI is not good at all.  You can simply turtle through the game even on the 2nd highest difficulty. I haven't bothered with the highest difficulty yet, but I'm sure it is the same because the AI simply gets more resource boosts.  The devs also seem to have a habit of rehashing their games a lot, this being the 3rd iteration of Elemental.  I have not played Elemental or Fallen Enchantress, but I have read that they are almost the same as FE: Legendary Heroes.  I got this game at 75% so I was not disappointed, at 10$ there is still ample play and it is a good deal, but in the long run I would rather play Master of Magic, which seemed to have a bit more depth and more variety of creatures and magic. Edit: This game is no where near as good as Age of Wonders III. I will still leave a positive recommendation because I got this game for 10$ on sale, and because they game isn't completely horrible.  The ai  never seems to try and attack and that is the biggest problem with this game.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												great game, one of the best 4x fantasy games. the game has a great mixture of civ5 city building elements, tactical combat, questing, huge amount of customization (you can create / customize every unit) and rpg-elements (spells, heroes level up with skills etc.). the randomly generated maps are quite huge and add a huge amount of replayability.the game is admittedly not without it flaws, personally i would've liked some more diversity within the races, meaning having more like elves, dwarves or other fantasy tropes instead of more human-like races...but this is of course a personal matter. another weak point comes from one of its strong points...being able to fully customize units means that you can basically create some powercreeps, there is no strong unist with some huge counters to them.....there is nothing like cavalry is good against swordsman, which are good are gainst archers, archers good against pikeman and pikeman are good against cavalry (cause of bony / mali etc.). it comes more down to the fact of creating strong troops which hit hard, have high initative and can also take a good amount of beating. that said, the game remains challenging and interesting througout the stages of the game, wildlands make for some really good settling sites but are guarded by boss-monster types of units. there are some pretty interesting ideas in the game and stardock is still supporting this game, releasing a 2.0 version after they've released SK and galciv3...some nice things ahead and i can recommend this game to every 4x fantasy lover :).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												BLUF: The game isn't worth $30, I paid a total of $14 for Elemental (the first one), and FE:LH (this one) - I'm a sales hunter. I have no misgivings, FE:LH (this one) has everything in it that Elemental did. So, if you're going to buy one, skip to this one. Detail:So, I enjoy modding this game. I'm going to say that right up front... so let me break this into two separate sections, vanilla and not.Vanilla:It's a passable strategy game with elements of RPG but not enough to call it an RPG game. Don't come in expecting Civ because that's stupid. Aside from the developers, I see nobody saying anything about Civ in relation to the game except in reviews from people saying its not like Civ (which they expected due to Devs who worked in ome way on Civ). The game play is pretty straight forward - make units, fight on a tactical grid-map. Use Block to reduce damage from hits, Dodge to avoid hits (even ranged), and spell resist to avoid magic or damage from magic. The built in options to customize a faction, a hero (sovereign), and your own units lend replability to the game. The AI will use created factions as "minor races" if you aren't using them in a scenario. Always nice.While this is billed as a the Fallen Enchantress come to enslave the world, thats really not it at all. There is a minor campaign that took a tops of 3 hours to complete (and only that cause I like to wander). That dealt with the enchantress, but even then, she was one of the easiest to beat factions. The game is really about random scenarios against random (or selected) factions including your custom ones. It IS buggy in some annoying spots:  -  Basically anywhere that you enter text runs into issues (such as custom facions backstory and custom Hero Backstory).   -  Custom maps have issues erasing each other in the cartographer tool  -  Altering generated maps in the Cartographer Tool will sometimes cause creatures to spawn on ocen-cliff tiles and make them unkillable outside of magic  -  You can only kill the Vanilla "Ridiculous" difficulty setting (well all of them) aren't vastly different from the normal in my experience.  -  It crashes infrequently, but the autosave feature makes it only a mildly annoying issue (for me).Modded:The scripting is pretty easy and straight forward. You can even port in 3D models if you're so inclined. The game was intended for modding but isn't set up for the Steam community. In fact, I doubt its even set up for Stardock (not that I've ever been there). I use NEXUS forums if I hit a roadblock or want to see what others have done. You can even alter the AI behavior to make the game more challenging, nerf ranged attacks if that's your piece, or do as some folks did and overhaul the game. Or, if you're lazy, download their versions and have the game overhauled for you. Also, you can add in items or nerf existing ones if you feel the game is all about who has the bigger stick.   - Some folks have claimed to fix the above vanilla bugs, I haven't experienced that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												Fallen Enchantress Legendary Heroes (FELH) is a rock solid game that is filled with a lot of great content (when adding in DLC) and ideas. The problem is much of the cotnent are set pieces in the game and new things don't happen often enough to make the world feel dynamic or lived in.  That is a problem.  You either steamroll eveything by midgame or complete the huge quests late when it doesn't really add much.Combat at the strategic level is usually fairly easy.  The CPU soes not really seem to know how to use its armies and will invariably park all of them in cities, unless it can be roused to enter a fight.  Unfortunately these armies are eithe rnot well contructed, updated or used effectively.  Like I said even in all out war the AI parks them.  So you conquer everything else and then go for the killing blow.  On a tactical level combat can become quite challenging and the AI seems to handle this aspect of combat better.The DLC is a mixed bag.  There is some good stuff like the undead, but the items and maps packs feel more like a donation to Stardock than great additions.  I did but them all, mostly when on sale (2.50 is a better price point).  What is missing is a workshop.  This is what makes GalCiv3 so awesome, user created content.  Even the ability to make magic items was something Master of Magic had... 25 years ago.The ability to customize your own race/wizard is really cool and for the most part superior to Master of Magic.... save for one thing, this is humans and undead only.  As in everything, save for a few monstrous units from spells.  You want elves, dwarved, halflings, gnomes?  Best of luck, chump.  Units can be cusomized and upgraded too, which is cool and while there ar eoptimal paths there are also lots of options that can differentiate units.  Sadly there are no fun mercinary units to hire like Master of Magic either.  Getting back to races a cool thing about MoM was that you could conquer cities and those cities made different units (big difference between a dark eld city and a human one...).  As you progress in FELH you will pick up heroes and they can be customized to some degree (earlier ones more so than later ones).  They can get gear and expand thier skills/abilities.  Here there are a few more racial options, but for the most part its a humans club.  The great balance here is that while heroes are awsome and powerful you really need an army to bloster them especially early but even later units of heavy cav and wizards do wonders to help them.Anyways this is a fun game and while I iwsh it were more of a challange, had a workshop and more variety in almost everything it has to offer from quests to races... FELH still is a great game and a worthy inheritor to the bar set by Master of Magic for a 4x game.  While it does bring that old game forward with the basics, what is missing is not only noticeable, but glaring.  Which is a shame.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												Master of Magic left a legacy and a hole that's never quite been filled. As far as turn-based fantasy strategy games go, this probably comes the closest. Yeah, the graphics are terrible, but honestly I don't care a lot about graphics in a strategy game. Endless Legend made  really pretty strategy game and while it's nice, it doesn't feel as robust as Fallen Enchantress. There's tons and tons of content, and even playing the same race / sovereign multiple times will give you a different experience. In fact if I had to call out one failing, it'd be the AI, but the AI in most other strategy games also super sucks, so this is pretty much par for the course. I realize that this game was built upon the crap-fest that was Elemental : War of Magic, but this is also a testament to what developers can do when they get community feedback on why their game sucked. What we have today works and is a lot of fun. Still haven't gotten a mage high enough to summon Delin though, and that makes me sad.  :'(

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 9
												One of the best "4x" games I have played. Takes the best of empire building and macro management from the 4x genre and melds it with levelling, talents, spells, skill trees etc that you would see in an RPG game like Dragon Age.The battle system is hands down the best one that I have come across in a 4X game. Once you engage an enemy, you move your units around on a grid and use skills and spells - turn based like Heroes of Might and Magic.There are so many spells and skills, and various roles your champions can take on.Many spells can be used on the map itself, to enchant cities, change the landscape, summon armies, and my personal favourite - dropping a 1200 mana cost volcano in the middle of the enemy capital city.The maps are beautiful and draw you into the world, there are so many different monsters (barbarians) to slaughter, camps and dungeons to loot, countless quests to undertake, all the while keeping your enemies in check and managing your kingdom/empire.Units can be customised with the unit editor, they have included all the developer tools - so the the limit is your imagination. If you ever find yourself getting a bit bored (hasn't happened yet for me!) there are many mods to download and try!It may have had a rough start, but it is very stable now and I have not encountered any major crashes / bugs as of yet.Highly recommended!
